descripGrp.descrip: To terminate a session with a computer accessed through a communications line usually a computer that is both distant and open to many users.
In communications, the portion of a Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) device that sends data.
A transmission medium designed for high-speed data transfers over long distances. Cable modem services and Digital Subscriber Line (DSL) are examples of broadband networks.
A mark placed over, under, or through a character, usually to indicate a change in phonetic value from the unmarked state.
A feature that allows you to open any XAML file on your hard disk (or a hyperlink on a web page) and run it within a browser without compilation.
A menu that drops from the menu bar when requested and remains open without further action until the user closes it or chooses a menu item.

The movement of information from one location to another, either within a computer (as from a disk drive to memory), between a computer and an external device (as between a file server and a computer on a network), or between separate computers.

A server located on a network between client software, such as a Web browser, and another server. It intercepts all requests to the server to determine whether it can fulfill them itself. If not, it forwards the request to another server.
A note that helps users learn about the capabilities of a product and that helps them apply techniques and procedures specific their needs by suggesting alternative methods that are not obvious.
A method of protecting the rights of an originator of a creative work, such as a text, a piece of music, a painting, or a computer program, through law.
A webpage that serves as the starting point of a website.
An association established between common fields (columns) in two tables. A relationship can be one-to-one, many-to-many, or one-to-many.
The inability of a computer system or related device to operate reliably or to operate at all.
An on-screen element whose location changes as the user moves the mouse.
An on-screen element whose location changes as the user moves the mouse.
A part of the user interface dedicated to a particular purpose, such as "instant message area."
The data access interface that communicates with OLE DB-compliant data sources to connect to, retrieve, manipulate, and update data.
A keyboard key that alternates between turning a particular operation, function, or mode on or off.
To change to a newer, and/or more powerful or sophisticated version of a product.
An orientation where the long dimension of a rectangular area (for example, screen, photo, or paper) is vertical.​
Any combination of keys that must be pressed simultaneously.
Any combination of keys that must be pressed simultaneously.
A digital document used for authentication and network security that binds a public key to an entity that holds the corresponding private key.
To gain entry to memory in order to read or write data.
A signal sent by a device to get the attention of the processor when the device is ready to accept or send information.
An object created using drawing tools or commands.
Any temporary storage space used within or in conjunction with a computer, such as RAM or a USB flash drive.
A unit of computer or device memory equal to 1,024 megabytes (1,024 1,048,576, [230] bytes).
A unit of computer or device memory equal to 1,024 megabytes (1,024 1,048,576, [230] bytes).
A standard Windows control that supports scrolling.
To organize information, such as a list of files, in a particular order. For example, a list of files can be sorted alphabetically by name in ascending or descending order.
An XML vocabulary that is used to transform XML data to another form, such as HTML, by means of a style sheet that defines presentation rules.
To press and release a mouse button twice in rapid succession without moving the mouse. Double-clicking is a means of rapidly selecting and activating a program or program feature.
The operational state of a computer or a program.
Any disk drive, folder, or other place in which you can store files and folders. Programs will commonly ask you to choose a location to save a file.
Software that enables hardware (e.g. peripherals) to work with your computer or mobile device.
Software that enables hardware (e.g. peripherals) to work with your computer or mobile device.
A set of technologies that allows software components to interact with one another in a networked environment, regardless of the language in which the components were created.
A connection between an OLE object and its OLE server, or between a dynamic data exchange (DDE) source document and a destination document.
To set up hardware and software.
A location on a SharePoint site where a collection of files and their associated metadata are stored.
A location on a SharePoint site where a collection of files and their associated metadata are stored.

A hardware- or software-based interface used to transfer information between a computer and other devices. Hardware ports are physical connections that are visible on the outside of the computer. Software ports are the numbered gateways in programs that software programs use to exchange information.
Referring to anything that is ready for immediate use by a user or application.
A database instance that makes data available for replication to other servers.
The timing and sequence of tasks within a project.

An input device used to control an on-screen cursor for such actions as "pressing" on-screen buttons in dialog boxes, choosing menu items, and selecting ranges of cells in spreadsheets or groups of words in a document.
Without difficulty.
An object that is inserted into a document from a source file and that is updated when the original source file is updated.

A tested, cumulative set of all hotfixes, security updates, critical updates and updates, as well as additional fixes for problems found internally since the release of the product. Service packs may also contain a limited number of customer requested design changes or features, and contain all fixes since the previous service pack or RTM.

In reference to a single microcomputer, the sum of a system's internal and external components, including memory, disk drives, keyboard, video, and generally less critical add-on hardware, such as a mouse, modem, or printer. Software (the operating system and various device drivers), the user's choices established through configuration files such as the AUTOEXEC.BAT and CONFIG.SYS files on IBM PCs and compatibles, and sometimes hardware (switches and jumpers) are needed to "configure the configuration" to work correctly. Although system configuration can be changed, as by adding more memory or disk capacity, the basic structure of the system--its architecture--remains the same.
A type of chart that displays the trend of values over time or categories. By displaying the sum of the plotted values, an area chart also shows the relationship of parts to a whole.
To reconcile the differences between two sets of stored data, where once the differences are determined, both sets are updated to be the same.
To reconcile the differences between two sets of stored data, where once the differences are determined, both sets are updated to be the same.
Any of four keys labeled with arrows pointing up, down, left, and right, used to move the cursor vertically or horizontally on the display screen or, in some programs, to extend the highlight.

A folder that provides you with a convenient place to store documents, graphics, or other files you want to access quickly. When you save a file in a program such as WordPad or Paint, the file is automatically saved in My Documents, unless you choose a different folder.

To transfer information either to a storage device, such as a disk, or to an output device, such as the monitor or a printer. Writing is the means by which a computer provides the results of processing. A computer can also be said to write to the screen when it displays information on the monitor.

A tool or software program designed to detect and respond to malicious software, such as viruses and worms. Responses may include blocking user access to infected files, cleaning infected files or systems, or informing the user that an infected program was detected.

A tool or software program designed to detect and respond to malicious software, such as viruses and worms. Responses may include blocking user access to infected files, cleaning infected files or systems, or informing the user that an infected program was detected.
Any self-contained piece of work created with an application program and, if saved on disk, given a unique filename by which it can be retrieved.
Any self-contained piece of work created with an application program and, if saved on disk, given a unique filename by which it can be retrieved.

A type of object within a process that runs program instructions. Using multiple threads allows concurrent operations within a process and enables one process to run different parts of its program on different processors simultaneously. A thread has its own set of registers, its own kernel stack, a thread environment block, and a user stack in the address space of its process.
Not visible to the user.
To transfer digital data in a continuous flow across a network.
Hardware that transfers audio and video from an external source, such as a VCR or camcorder, to a computer.

On the IBM PC/XT and AT and compatible keyboards, a key on the top row of the numeric keypad that controls the effect of the cursor control keys and sometimes prevents the screen from scrolling. On the enhanced and Macintosh keyboards, this key is to the right of the function keys on the top row. Many modern applications ignore the Scroll Lock setting.

In object-oriented programming, a language that lets a program or object written in one language communicate with another program written in an unknown language. An IDL is used to define interfaces between client and server programs. For example, an IDL can provide interfaces to remote CORBA objects.
A graphic design applied to a collection of numbers, symbols, and characters and that describes a certain typeface, along with other qualities such as size, spacing, and pitch.

An operating system feature that allows executable routines (generally serving a specific function or set of functions) to be stored separately as files with .dll extensions. These routines are loaded only when needed by the program that calls them.
Digital media that is delivered in a continuous flow across a network.
An entity, such as a device or program, that connects to another entity over a network.
To remove unused space from data tables.
The item on the File menu that writes data (typically a file) to a storage medium.
Text or symbols indicating that a computer program is waiting for input from the user.
An on-screen scale marked off in inches or other units of measure and used to show line widths, tab settings, paragraph indents, and so on.
To gain access to a specific computer, program, or network by identifying oneself with a username and a password.

The work area on a computer screen that simulates the top of an actual desk. The desktop contains the Recycle Bin and other icons (shortcuts to programs, files, folders, and various types of documents such as letters, reports, or pictures) that you can arrange on the electronic desktop just as you would arrange real objects on top of a desk.

The process of starting or resetting a computer or a device. When first turned on (cold boot) or reset (warm boot), the computer runs the software that loads and starts the computer's operating system, which prepares it for use.

Management of a computer and its processing abilities so as to maintain order as tasks and activities are carried out. Control applies to measures designed to ensure error-free actions carried out at the right time and in the right order relative to other data-handling or hardware-based activities.
Of or pertaining to a device or service that appears to the user as something it actually is not or that does not physically exist.

Having two components, alternatives, or outcomes. The binary number system has 2 as its base, so values are expressed as combinations of two digits, 0 and 1. These two digits can represent the logical values true and false as well as numerals, and they can be represented in an electronic device by the two states on and off, recognized as two voltage levels. Therefore, the binary number system is at the heart of digital computing.
A variable-length data type that can hold a maximum of 2^30 - 1 (1,073,741,823) characters.
How a program's action is determined if the user does not make a choice or supply a required value.
A note or annotation that an author or reviewer adds to a document.
A binary number that uniquely identifies a host (computer) connected to the Internet to other Internet hosts, for the purposes of communication through the transfer of packets.
A process for removing redundant data from a digital media file or stream to reduce its size or the bandwidth used.
A distinctive symbol that identifies a person, business, or organization.
An agreement between a service provider and a customer that specifies the amount and type of service the provider will deliver.
To translate all the source code of a program from a high-level language into object code prior to execution of the program.
Dialog from film or video displayed on the screen (usually at the bottom) and typically used to provide translation from a foreign language.
To display the subentries contained within a folder or outline view.
A system of programs and workstations used in designing engineering, architectural, and scientific models ranging from simple tools to buildings, aircraft, integrated circuits, and molecules.

The key arrangement used for a particular keyboard, including such factors as the number of keys (101 is the current standard) and the configuration of the keys (QWERTY is the United States standard). Some proprietary systems use different layouts, and many allow you to map the keys to characters according to your preferences.
The individual, or account, to whom an email message is sent.
A software system that enables applications to interact with hardware and that manages software resources on a computer.
To press and release a mouse button once without moving the mouse, usually to select or deselect an item or to activate a program or program feature.

The degree to which a computer, an attached device, a data file, or a program can work with or understand the same commands, formats, or language as another. True compatibility means that any operational differences are invisible to people and programs alike.

Existing in reference to two measures, such as height and width--for example, a two-dimensional model drawn with reference to an x-axis and a y-axis, or a two-dimensional array of numbers placed in rows and columns.
Pertaining to something for which an answer is not available or appropriate.
Text displayed by Web browsers during image downloads for users who have graphics turned off, and for users who rely on screen-reading software to convert graphics on the screen to spoken words.
Text displayed by Web browsers during image downloads for users who have graphics turned off, and for users who rely on screen-reading software to convert graphics on the screen to spoken words.
The point size of a set of characters in a particular typeface.
A toggle key that, when on, shifts the alphabetic characters on the keyboard to uppercase.
A toggle key that, when on, shifts the alphabetic characters on the keyboard to uppercase.
A user’s private information such as temporary files, history, passwords, web form entries, and cookies that captures Internet surfing and other online activities.
A set of strategies for adjusting the recognizer to an individual’s user’s handwriting, e.g. the shapes of their characters or the specific words they use and don’t use.

A set of routines that an application uses to request and carry out lower-level services performed by a computer's or device's operating system. These routines usually carry out maintenance tasks such as managing files and displaying information.
A data type used in some programming languages, notably C, to declare variables that can store floating-point numbers.
To reduce the size of a set of data, such as a file or a communications message, so that it can be stored in less space or transmitted with less bandwidth.
To extend over and cover a part of something.
An overlapped window used for dialog boxes, message boxes, and other temporary windows that appear outside an application's primary window.
An optical disc format used to store video on standard compact discs developed by China Recording Standards Committee in competition to the DVD format.
The indication that the phone is busy.
An orientation of printed paper where the printed side is against a surface. For example, paper is face down when it is placed in a copier with the printed side against the copying surface.
A pictorial graphic such as a digital photograph or illustration.
A pictorial graphic such as a digital photograph or illustration.

An advanced file system designed for use specifically with the Windows NT operating system. It supports long filenames, full security access control, file system recovery, extremely large storage media, and various features for the Windows NT POSIX subsystem. It also supports object-oriented applications by treating all files as objects with user-defined and system-defined attributes.

A technology that provides persistent protection to digital data using encryption, certificates, and authentication. Authorized recipients or users must acquire a license in order to consume the protected files, according to the rights, or business rules, set by the content owner.
The feature of Microsoft SQL Server used to import, export, and transform data from different data sources.

The standard used to measure screen and printer resolution, expressed as the number of dots that a device can display or print per linear inch. The greater the number of dots per inch, the better the resolution.

The right of a person or entity to use software in a particular way, as described in the terms of the license agreement. Copyright law also limits how a person may use the software. A person needs a license agreement for each software program they use.
A group of related web pages that is hosted by an HTTP server on the World Wide Web or an intranet.
A group of related web pages that is hosted by an HTTP server on the World Wide Web or an intranet.
A group of related web pages that is hosted by an HTTP server on the World Wide Web or an intranet.
Properties, such as title, subject, and author, that are stored with each data access page.
Pertaining to a type of layout consisting of a collection of “Row-Wise Groupings”. A stacked layout most resembles a form with name/value pairs (label, textbox).

The suite of networking protocols arranged in four layers, which are called the link layer, internet layer, transport layer, and application layer, and that includes IP in the internet layer and TCP in the transport layer.

An optical input device that uses light-sensing equipment to capture an image on paper or some other object. Captured image data is converted into binary files that can be stored and manipulated by computer programs.
A group of computers that are connected on a network and share resources, such as printers and files.
The processes involved in the capture, storage, display, and printing of graphical images.
To emphasize displayed characters, as by displaying them in reverse video (light on dark rather than dark on light, and vice versa) or against a colored background.
A collection of data formatted to allow for easy search and retrieval.
An object in a filesystem that contains files and other directories.
Pertaining to an entity such as the device, program, file, record or portion of the screen that is currently operational or subject to command operations.
A value that a function or a method receives from a caller to perform computations.
The likelihood of a computer system or device continuing to function over a given period of time and under specified conditions.
A key on IBM PC and compatible keyboards that normally causes the computer to send a character-based “picture” of the screen contents to the printer.
A symbol that carries meaning in language, such as a letter, number, punctuation mark, or emoticon.
In I/O operations, to prevent execution of a thread.
To halt a process or action, typically without restoring the prior state.

The electronic circuit in a computer that generates a steady stream of timing pulses--the digital signals that synchronize every operation. The system clock signal is precisely set by a quartz crystal, typically at a specific frequency between 1 and 50 megahertz. The clock rate of a computer is one of the prime determinants of its overall processing speed, and it can go as high as the other components of the computer allow.
Pertaining to Microsoft software which is published by Microsoft, properly licensed, and fully supported by Microsoft or a trusted partner.
A grouping of properties presented as a tabbed page of a property sheet.
The W3C standard language used for writing XML schema documents.
A distinct chunk of text that is indicated by formatting such as indentation, numbering, or a new line.
In word processing, a string of characters displayed or printed in a single horizontal row.

The process of viewing and updating the actual progress of tasks so that you can see progress across time, evaluate slippage of tasks, compare scheduled or baseline data to actual data, and check the completion percentage of tasks and your project.
The programming language designed at Microsoft that was derived from BASIC and that was designed to enable the easy development of visual applications and components in Windows.
A line added to a chart that makes it easier to view and evaluate data.
A program that invokes other programs in order to accomplish its tasks.
A computer hardware component providing access to a network.
To remove part of a document, usually placing it temporarily in memory so that the cut portion can be inserted (pasted) elsewhere.
Descriptive text that is associated with a piece of content, such as an image.
A property of a field that defines the kinds of data the field can store.
A form of storage characterized by high capacity (roughly 650 MB) and the use of laser optics instead of magnetic means for reading data.
To delay an item, such as a reminder, an alarm, or a recommendation, by a specified time.
To make resources, such as folders, printers, files, photos, available to others.
To execute a group of statements repeatedly.
To change a system or a data file to make it more current.
A property that defines valid input values for a field or record in a table, or a control on a form.
Able to be both read from and written to.
In an Active Directory forest, a server that contains a writable copy of the Active Directory database, participates in Active Directory replication, and controls access to network resources.
In an Active Directory forest, a server that contains a writable copy of the Active Directory database, participates in Active Directory replication, and controls access to network resources.

The process of validating software with the manufacturer. Activation confirms the genuine status of a product and that the product key has not been compromised. It establishes a relationship between the software’s product key and a particular installation of that software on a device.

Software that enables a program to work with the user (the user interface, which can be a command-line interface, menu-driven, or a graphical user interface), with another program such as the operating system, or with the computer's hardware.
A feature of Windows that checks for problems associated with network connections.
To load the program and installation files onto your computer or device so that the program runs correctly.
A symbolic value used in place of a real value that is unknown or unavailable at the current time, or that is not displayed for security reasons.

Capable of using or being displayed on the full area of a display screen. Applications running in windowing environments, although they might use the entire area of the screen, commonly allocate different areas to different windows, any of which can be enlarged to fill the entire screen.
To make an entity nonfunctional.
A round, flat piece of nonmagnetic, shiny metal encased in a plastic coating, designed to be read from and written to by optical (laser) technology.
A device used to store information.
To put into use.
A designation used to conduct sorting or searching operations.
To enter numbers on a device, such as telephone or mobile, in order to make a phone call.
A graphic symbol used on the user interface to assist with navigation.
An area of storage that is formatted with a file system and has an identifier to access it.
A program that searches for key words in documents, databases, Internet content or other files.
A list of entities such as people, groups, or organizations with whom users communicate.
A combination of keystrokes that can be used to perform a task that would otherwise require a mouse or other pointing device.
A graphical control used to display text.
In mathematics, an action performed on a set of entities that produces a new entity. Examples of mathematical operations are addition and subtraction.
A successful retrieval of a record matching a query.
The process of validating content before publishing.
A view on a calendar that displays items such as meetings and events from left to right on a time scale and that can incorporate items from multiple calendars.
To modify the value of a property or attribute.
A definition of the structure of a particular type of data, which includes a definition of the allowed attributes and allowed relationships with other objects.
A page where there is no information displayed
A unit of information within a markup language that is defined by a tag, or a pair of tags surrounding some content, and includes any attributes defined within the initial tag.
An area of memory reserved for temporarily holding data before that data is used by a receiving device or application. Buffering protects against the interruption of data flow.
A horizontal bar at the top of a window that displays the name of the window.
Of, pertaining to, or characterized by capital letters.

A data type that will provide support for storing binary files within an Access database. More similar to the SharePoint concept of attachments than the current OLE object fields in Access. The data will be stored as a raw blob within the database.
Damaged. Mostly used in regard to files or data.
An individual box or button with which users enter information on an electronic form.
A quality of a product to be directly or indirectly usable by individuals with disabilities.
A searchable collection of articles and facts about a particular subject area.
A piece of software that functions as an electronic calendar used for scheduling.
Generally, any part of a computer system or network, such as a disk drive, printer, or memory, that can be allotted to a running program or a process.
A rectangular bar displayed in an application's window, often at the top, from which menus can be selected by the user.
A message that appears at a specified interval before an appointment, meeting, or task that announces when the activity is set to occur.
To change between states or modes.
To associate two pieces of information with one another.
A person responsible for planning, configuring, and managing the day-to-day operation of the network.
An attribute of an object that is used to define its state, appearance, or value.
A microcomputer designed for use by one person at a time. Personal computers do not need to share the processing, disk, and printer resources of another computer.
The amount of battery power left on the system.
The amount of battery power left on the system.
In programming, the order and sequence of input and output.
The date after which information or a resource is no longer valid.

A predefined set of harmonized colors that you can apply to text and objects. Text and objects with an applied scheme color will change automatically when you switch to a new color scheme or modify the current color scheme.
A document listing common questions and answers on a particular subject.
A space, shown onscreen as a box, that contains a particular element of your publication.
To bring information from one system or program into another.
A meaningful shorthand that makes it easier to understand the purpose of a cell reference, constant, formula, or table, each of which may be difficult to comprehend at first glance.
A reusable magnetic storage medium. The floppy disk used today is the rigid 3.5-inch microfloppy that holds 1.44 MB. It is called floppy because the first varieties were housed in bendable jackets.
A reusable magnetic storage medium. The floppy disk used today is the rigid 3.5-inch microfloppy that holds 1.44 MB. It is called floppy because the first varieties were housed in bendable jackets.
A portable computer that combines a processor, screen, and keyboard in a single case. The screen folds down onto the keyboard when not in use.
In operating systems, the process of reserving memory for use by a program.
A shaded outline that appears behind an object or text and creates the illusion of depth.
A shaded outline that appears behind an object or text and creates the illusion of depth.

An Intel microprocessor that uses explicitly parallel instruction set computing and 64-bit memory addressing. "Itanium-based" refers to systems or platforms that are based on the Itanium processor. "Itanium2-based" refers to systems or platforms that are based on the Itanium2 processor. "Itanium architecture-based" refers to systems or platforms that are based on the Itanium and Itanium2 processors.
A group of characters that have some relationship in common.
The vertical bar at the right of a window that users can click to move through a document.
The vertical bar at the right of a window that users can click to move through a document.
A menu item with options that can be applied to a file before it is shared with others (e.g. 'Mark as Final' or 'Add a Digital Signature').

An application commonly used for budgets, forecasting, and other finance-related tasks that organizes data values using cells, where the relationships between cells are defined by formulas. A change to one cell produces changes to related cells. Spreadsheet programs usually provide graphing capabilities for output and a variety of formatting options for text, numeric values, and graph features.
A file that contains configuration information for a specific user, such as desktop settings, persistent network connections, and application settings.
A copy of a database that is a member of a replica set and can be synchronized with other replicas in the set.
A performer of a song or other audio recording.
The process of adding software to a computer system.
Of, pertaining to, or being an object or image having or appearing to have all three spatial dimensions (length, width, and depth).
Of, pertaining to, or being an object or image having or appearing to have all three spatial dimensions (length, width, and depth).
The complementary tasks of gathering and distributing data. Input is data that is acquired from a device or entered by the user through a device. Output is data that is sent to a device.

The creation of an image containing geometric models, using color and shading to give the image a realistic look. Usually part of a geometric modeling package such as a CAD program, rendering uses mathematics to describe the location of a light source in relation to the object and to calculate the way in which the light would create highlights, shading, and variations in color. The degree of realism can range from opaque, shaded polygons to images approximating photographs in their complexity.
The Microsoft owned technology that allows the embedding and linking of objects, such as documents, allowing for the addition of different kinds of data from different applications.
A small device used to store information. USB flash drives plug into computer USB ports so you can copy information to or from them, making it easy to share and transport information.
A small device used to store information. USB flash drives plug into computer USB ports so you can copy information to or from them, making it easy to share and transport information.
A set of possible values for an independent variable in a function or for a database attribute.
A chunk of data that a Web server sends to a browser, which in turn saves it and sends it back when accessing the Web server again.

The ability of a word-processing program or a text-editing program to break lines of text automatically to stay within the page margins or window boundaries of a document without the user having to do so with carriage returns, as is typically necessary on a typewriter.

The ability of a word-processing program or a text-editing program to break lines of text automatically to stay within the page margins or window boundaries of a document without the user having to do so with carriage returns, as is typically necessary on a typewriter.

A value that is used in Microsoft Points to enable efficient micropayments and prepaid purchase for cash based consumers (including kids/teens, as well as emerging and developing markets) and provide a mechanism to directly reward loyal customers.

A directory of information about data sets, files, or a database. It usually describes where a data set, file or database entity is located and may also include other information, such as the type of device on which each data set or file is stored.
An organization that provides a connection to the internet and services related to that.
An organization that provides a connection to the internet and services related to that.

Self-propagating malicious software that can automatically distribute itself from one computer to another through network connections. A worm can take harmful action, such as consuming network or local system resources, possibly causing a denial of service attack.
A security solution that segregates one portion of a network from another portion, allowing only authorized network traffic to pass through according to traffic filtering rules.
A listing of keywords and associated data that point to the location of more comprehensive information, such as files and records on a disk or record keys in a database.

The special identification code printed as a set of vertical bars of differing widths on books, grocery products, and other merchandise. Used for rapid, error-free input in such facilities as libraries, hospitals, and grocery stores, bar codes represent binary information that can be read by an optical scanner. The coding can include numbers, letters, or a combination of the two; some codes include built-in error checking and can be read in either direction.
A software technique for smoothing the jagged appearance of curved or diagonal lines caused by poor resolution on a display screen by adjusting the brightness or color of surrounding pixels.
An interactive controls often found in graphical user interfaces used to enable or disable one or more features or options from a set.

An input device with the following features: a flat-bottomed casing designed to be gripped by one hand; one or more buttons on the top; a multidirectional detection device (a ball, laser or optical device) on the bottom; and a cable or wireless connection to the computer.
A utility or feature that aids in accomplishing a task or set of tasks.
A type of CD-ROM that can be written (only once) on a CD recorder and read on a CD-ROM drive.
The ability of hardware devices, software packages, or a computer itself to work with network devices or with other hardware devices, software packages, or a computer over a network connection.
A feature introduced with Windows 2000 that allows administrators to enforce computer-specific and user-specific settings to domain-based computers.
A category for grouping or describing multimedia or games, such as music categorized as "classical" or "jazz".
A DVD from which the video section can be played on the DVD set top box. When inserted in the PC, the user can access additional features such as games, web links etc.
A photographic style and filter name that renders a photo in brown tones, mimicking the old-fashioned look of photos taken in the early part of the 20th century.
A pattern or mask through which data is passed to separate specified items.
A hardware type for digital cameras and scanners.
A standard Windows icon that represents a user’s private, usually local, storage.
A record of transactions or events that take place within an IT managed environment.
To cause text or an image to visually fade.
Pertaining to a process or content that is not associated with an identifiable user or originator.

A computer that acts as a source of information or signals. The host computer provides services, such as news, mail, or data, to computers that connect to it. The term can refer to almost any kind of computer, from a centralized mainframe that is a host to its terminals, to a server that is host to its clients, to a desktop PC that is host to its devices, such as printers and scanners.

A pointing device used mainly but not exclusively for computer games. A joystick has a base, on which control buttons can be mounted, and a vertical stem, which the user can move in any direction to control the movement of an object on the screen.
In reference to one or more computers, connected to a network.
The location (drive, folder, or directory) to which a file is copied or moved.

A written order on a bank to pay a sum of money from funds in an account. Checks show the name of the company or individual receiving payment, the signature and account number of the person issuing the check, the payment amount and the current date. Checks usually are numbered in sequence.
Protection of a computer system and its data from harm or loss.

A physical hardware unit that can connect portable computers to a power source and to peripherals, such as a monitor, printer, full-sized keyboard, or mouse. The connection can be wireless or physical.
A file that contains some pre-defined formatting, layout, and/or text and graphics and that serves as the basis for new content with a similar look or purpose.
An arrangement of network devices that defines which devices are connected together.
An arrangement of network devices that defines which devices are connected together.
To copy files to a recordable CD.
A window that displays data from a table, form, query, view, or stored procedure in a row-and-column format.
A certification authority that has the ability to issue the intermediate certificates needed to certify the subject identified by the end certificate.
A certification authority that has the ability to issue the intermediate certificates needed to certify the subject identified by the end certificate.
A window that displays a form to either show or accept data. Form view is the primary means of adding and modifying data in tables. You cannot change the design of a form in this view.

A plastic (credit card–sized or smaller) device with an embedded microprocessor and a small amount of storage that is used, with an access code, to enable certificate-based authentication. Smart cards securely store certificates, public and private keys, passwords, and other types of personal information.

A plastic (credit card–sized or smaller) device with an embedded microprocessor and a small amount of storage that is used, with an access code, to enable certificate-based authentication. Smart cards securely store certificates, public and private keys, passwords, and other types of personal information.
A color that that is currently selected for drawing or displaying text on the screen.
On a Web page, a grouping of hyperlinks for getting around in that particular Web site.
The entity designated to receive something.
To provide services (often using a server) to client computers that connect from remote locations, for example, to offer Internet access or to be the source for a news or mail service.
A collection of information that is stored on a computer or device under a single name.
The process of verifying the identity of an entity, such as a user, computer, device, process, by validating the credentials provided by the entity.
A string of text that is displayed with one value for each text attribute: typeface, slant, and weight.
A process of converting readable data (plaintext) into a coded form (ciphertext) to prevent it from being read by an unauthorized party.
A data-entry field on a page. A site visitor supplies information in a field either by typing text or by selecting a field.
A data type used to hold date and time information.
Pertaining to an entity, such as a user, a file or a computer that is currently connected a server.
The range and depth of a search on a portal site, desktop or other.
The value of a scorecard element in relation to the values of other elements of the same type.
To follow the flow of information; to monitor progress.
The Office feature that automatically corrects errors and makes other substitutions as soon as a user types text.

A keyboard key that, when pressed in combination with another key, gives that key an alternative meaning, for example, producing an uppercase character when a letter key is pressed. The SHIFT key is also used in various key combinations to create nonstandard characters or to perform special operations.
A condition in which paper is blocked in the printing path of a printer, scanner, photocopier or fax machine.
A type of expansion board on PC-compatible computers that allows the playback and recording of sound, such as from a WAV or MIDI file or a music CD-ROM. Most PCs sold at retail include a sound card.
To move selected items to another location for long term storage.
A diagram that is used to show hierarchical relationships; for example, company management and employee structures.
In object-oriented programming, a named code block that performs a task when called.
Pertaining to a value that indicates missing or unknown data.
An area that shows available network connections and helps users quickly connect to the most appropriate one.

All elements included in the Query window, such as tables, criteria, the order in which fields are arranged, and so on. The design also specifies whether Auto Query is turned on, and whether you can edit the source data.
The default tab on the ribbon interface that provides the basic features that users need most frequently for each application.
The replay of a digital media file.
A collection of elements that can be treated as a whole.
A format consisting of ASCII codes in which database, spreadsheet, and similar documents can be structured to facilitate their use by and transfer to other programs.
A set of records that results from running a query or applying a filter.
A message that is sent over a communications network such as a local area network or the Internet.
Pertaining to a disk to which content cannot be recorded.
A file backup feature that performs scheduled incremental backups of data to the target media. It also allows the user to restore an individual file or a group of files.
The uppermost directory on a computer, partition or volume.
The uppermost directory on a computer, partition or volume.
The protocol or protocols operating at a particular level within a protocol suite, such as IP within the TCP/IP suite.
The most trusted certification authority (CA), which is at the top of a certification hierarchy. The root CA has a self-signed certificate.
To remove something.
To show something.
A low grade of printing generated by the draft mode on dot-matrix printers. Draft quality varies among printers, ranging from suitable for most purposes to nearly useless.
A low grade of printing generated by the draft mode on dot-matrix printers. Draft quality varies among printers, ranging from suitable for most purposes to nearly useless.
To revoke an action by quitting it without saving any changes that it would result in.
An area in a window or record that stores a single data value.
A feature that makes the screen more readable by people who have low vision by creating a separate window that displays a magnified portion of the screen.
The key on the keyboard that is labeled with a right arrow.
A unique identifier that identifies a network node to other nodes on the network.
A marker that can be associated with content or items, such as photos or text, to identify certain types of information, and that allows users to find, view, and sort marked content.
A key that, when pressed in combination with another key, gives the other key an alternative meaning.
The organization (the arrangement, size, and position) of the visual elements in your application, with respect to each other and the overall application window.
A location in a hierarchy (often a tree structure) that can have links to one or more nodes below it.
A field that contains the result of a query to an external data source.
An Address Book that contains entries for every group, user, and contact within an organization's implementation of Exchange Server.
A section of space on a physical disk that functions as if it were a separate disk.
A section of space on a physical disk that functions as if it were a separate disk.
A large-format publication, typically with one dimension much larger than the other, that is printed with a symbol, logo, slogan or other message.
Pertaining to time when an individual has nothing scheduled and appears as available.
A communication line used for data transfer among the components of a computer system.
A distance between characters in a line of text.
A set of characters added to the end of a file name that identifies the file type or format.
A set of characters added to the end of a file name that identifies the file type or format.
A logical structure that organizes the members of a set into parent-child relationships.
A set of media selected by a user from a gallery, library or list.
A hardware device that reads data from and writes data to floppy disks.
A hardware device that reads data from and writes data to floppy disks.
A hardware device that reads data from and writes data to floppy disks.
To submit content to an online forum for others to see.
A value that is automatically used by a program when the user does not specify an alternative and are built into a program when a value or option must be assumed for the program to function.
To acknowledge an action or the value of some data (e.g. password) by definite assurance.
One or more special characters used to separate peers in a delimited structure, at any level (fields, records, and so on).
A descriptive or user-friendly label for a control or object, displayed on the screen. The display name may differ from the internal name.
A set of slides that are imported or created for display in a meeting.

A website from Microsoft which provides updates (patches and fixes) for multiple Microsoft products in one place, including Windows operating system software and Windows-based hardware, Microsoft Office system, Microsoft SQL Server, and Microsoft Exchange Server.
A standard set of formats and procedures that enable computers to exchange information.

The smallest unit of information handled by a computer or device. One bit expresses a 1 or a 0 in a binary numeral, or a true or false logical condition. A group of 8 bits makes up a byte, which can represent many types of information, such as a letter of the alphabet, a decimal digit, or other character.

The integral Windows component that supports building, deploying, and running the next generation of applications and XML Web services. It provides a highly productive, standards-based, multilanguage environment for integrating existing investments with next generation applications and services, as well as the agility to solve the challenges of deployment and operation of Internet-scale applications.
A data type that stores either a 1 or 0 value. Integer values other than 1 or 0 are accepted, but they are always interpreted as 1.
A measurement used for high-capacity data storage. One terabyte equals 240, or 1,099,511,627,776, bytes, although it is commonly interpreted as simply one trillion bytes.
A keyboard key that, when pressed (and held), changes the actions of ordinary input.
To transfer a copy of a file from a remote device to a requesting device by means of a modem or network.

A slide view or page on which you define formatting for all slides or pages in your presentation. Each presentation has a master for each key component: slides, title slides, speaker's notes, and audience handouts.
A visual output device aimed at displaying various type of information.
To make data ready and available for subsequent distribution and deployment in a server environment.
To make a chart sheet or worksheet the active, or selected, sheet. The sheet that you activate determines which menu bar and toolbars are displayed.

A power-saving state that allows the computer or device to quickly resume full-power operation (typically within several seconds) when you want to start working again. All open documents and programs are saved to memory before the computer or device enters the low-power state.
A sequence of activities, actions, or tasks through which documents or items are passed as part of an automated business process.
A method of payment by which a customer pays the freight carrier for goods when they are delivered. The freight carrier then remits the payment to the shipper.
A special memory subsystem in which frequently used data values are duplicated for quick access.
A user interface area in which users perform tasks.
A designation with the same meaning as another in the same language but often with different implications and associations.
To verify, test or control by comparison or examination.

The process an operating system uses to detect and record security-related events, such as an attempt to create, to access, or to delete objects such as files and directories. The records of such events are stored in a file known as a security log, whose contents are available only to those with the proper clearance.
Pertaining to a mixture of characters that are read from left to right and characters that are read from right to left.
Pertaining to a mixture of characters that are read from left to right and characters that are read from right to left.
The protocol within TCP/IP that governs the breakup of data messages into packets to be sent via IP, and the reassembly and verification of the complete messages from packets received by IP.

A database repository for information about a computer's configuration. The registry contains information that Windows continually references during operation, such as: profiles for each user; the programs installed on the computer and the types of documents that each can create; property settings for folders and program icons; what hardware exists on the system; which ports are being used. The registry is organized hierarchically as a tree, and it is made up of keys and their subkeys, hives, and entries.
A folder that stores the user's music library.
To explicitly decline to participate.
To join or link.
The state of an expression or a variable (for example, when a result can be either true or false, or equal or not equal).

A method used with SCSI and IDE disk drives to translate the cylinder, head, and sector specifications of the drive into addresses that can be used by an enhanced BIOS. LBA is used with drives that are larger than 528MB.
Pertaining to an entire entity such as document, file, or program rather than to a restricted segment of it.
A method of delivering digital media across a network in a continuous flow. The digital media is played by client software as it is received.
A measure of the fineness of detail in an image or text, usually as produced by a monitor or printer.
To move data from one location to another.

To put back into a stable condition. A computer user may be able to recover lost or damaged data by using a program to search for and salvage whatever information remains in storage. A database may be recovered by restoring its integrity after some problem has damaged it, such as abnormal termination of the database management program.
A semiconductor circuit that contains information that cannot be modified.
A value or condition that is not consistent with the true, specified, or expected value or condition.

The core of layered architecture that manages the most basic operations of the operating system and the computer's processor. The kernel schedules different blocks of executing code, called threads, for the processor to keep it as busy as possible and coordinates multiple processors to optimize performance. The kernel also synchronizes activities among Executive-level subcomponents, such as I/O Manager and Process Manager, and handles hardware exceptions and other hardware-dependent functions. The kernel works closely with the hardware abstraction layer.
A format of a file, commonly indicated by its file name extension, and indicates which program the file was created in and can be opened with.
A Windows feature that allows users to connect remotely to a computer and access programs, files, and network resources as though they were sitting at the computer.
A structured document or template with spaces reserved for entering information and often containing special coding (e.g. to trigger data processing).
The * character. Indicates multiplication in programming languages and also serves as a wildcard character representing one or more characters.
A group of OneNote sections.
The arrangement of text and graphics on the page of a document.

To add a special visual or sound effect to text or an object. For example, you can have your text bullet points fly in from the left, one word at a time, or hear the sound of applause when a picture is uncovered.

The process of finalizing a purchase on a website. For example, when customers shop on your website, they may select several items and save them in their shopping basket. When they have finished shopping, they click on a checkout link or graphical button that takes them to an online form where they enter their name, billing address, payment type, and shipping information.
In information processing, fixed or predetermined.
To carry on a real-time conversation with other users by computer or device.
A graphic, often appearing as a bitmap or a combination of drawn shapes, that can be inserted into content.
A listing of contents at the beginning of a document or file.
A listing of contents at the beginning of a document or file.
Help that is available to the user while not being connected to or part of a system or network.
Any combination of keys that must be pressed sequentially.

To move a document or other data in a window in order to view a particular portion of the document. Scrolling may be controlled by the mouse, arrow keys, or other keys on the keyboard, eventually with one or more fingers.
The Windows program that collects and displays for users the system-level features of the computer, including hardware and software setup and configuration.
A software that was installed on the system without user's consent.
A standard control that allows a user to select from a fixed set of mutually exclusive choices.
Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of communications that take place without the use of interconnecting wires or cables, such as by radio, microwave, or infrared.
To move around in a document.
In reference to a computing device or a program, unable to communicate with a primary database or controlling computer.
A commonly used file format for storing contact information. Contacts that use the vCard format are stored as .vcf files.
A collection of photos in electronic format that have been grouped into a virtual album.

An ad that is served to a user's screen either as a pushed (sent by email) or pulled ad (requested by a user's browser). This includes measurement of responses from an ad delivery system to a user's browser.
Pertaining to the state of an object when it is not the focus of a user's input.
Pertaining to tasks that need to be done.
A number specifying a location in memory where data is stored.
To transfer a file from one location to another where once the transfer is complete, there is only one copy of the file, in the new location.
A disk, file, document, or other collection of information from which data is taken or moved.
A disk, file, document, or other collection of information from which data is taken or moved.

A device that reads the information stored on a compact disc. A compact disc player contains the optical equipment necessary for reading a disc's contents and the electronic circuitry for interpreting the data as it is read.
To reduce the amount of information displayed by hiding from view the subentries within a folder, section or conversation, or a portion of text or other content within a control.
A unit of application logic providing data and services to other applications that can invoke Web protocols.
A one-stop shop for customizing Office deployment and setup behaviors.
Instructions that make hardware work.
A container that presents an array or grid of visual choices to a user for selection.

A group of characters or character bytes handled as a single entity. Computer programs use strings to store and transmit data and commands. Most programming languages consider strings (such as 2674:gstmn) as distinct from numeric values (such as 470924).

A connection between multiple tables where records from related fields that match are combined and shown as one record. Records that don't match may be included or excluded, depending on the type of join.
A user who creates or edits a document.
A sign or symbol that specifies the type of calculation to perform within an expression. There are mathematical, comparison, logical, and reference operators.
To configure settings to restrict access to or permissions for a file or specific elements within a file.
A program, routine, or process that performs a specific system function to support other programs.

The degree of difference between light and dark extremes of color on a monitor, device screen, or printed output, or between the darkest and lightest areas in a photo. The greater the difference, the higher the contrast.
A collection of entities, such as users, computers, contacts, and other groups that is used only for email distribution, and addressed as a single recipient.
A wizard that guides the user through installing a printer on their network.
A folder on another computer that has been made available for other people to use on the network.
A smart card that stores a subscriber's personal identifier, billing information, and data.
An object that enables user interaction or input, often to initiate an action, display information, or set values.
A link to any item accessible on your computer or on a network, such as a program or application, file, folder, disk drive, printer, or another computer.
A location or selection of text in a file that you name for reference purposes. Bookmarks identify a location within your file that you can later refer or link to.
The collection of custom properties for a shape.
A feature in Windows that uses add-in programs, or gadgets, to extend information from your computer onto secondary displays.
A feature in Windows that uses add-in programs, or gadgets, to extend information from your computer onto secondary displays.
To check program correctness by trying out various sequences and input values.
The visible line around the edge of an object. For example, the four lines of a rectangle that comprise its border.

A state in which your computer consumes less power when it is idle, but remains available for immediate use. While your computer is on standby, information in computer memory is not saved on your hard disk. If there is an interruption in power, the information in memory is lost.

A search feature associated with folders and programs that begins to display results as soon as a keyword is entered. When you enter text, files in the current view are automatically filtered to show only those that match what you typed.

A search feature associated with folders and programs that begins to display results as soon as a keyword is entered. When you enter text, files in the current view are automatically filtered to show only those that match what you typed.
A Control Panel icon in Windows Vista that takes user to the Power Options dialog box where the user can manage the battery life settings.
To stop the operation of a program or execution of a command temporarily.
The point at which one line ends and another begins.
To manipulate an interface element, such as a toolbar or panel, in order to align it with the edge of another interface element, typically a window or pane.
When referring to hardware, to physically connect the device to your computer, to load device drivers onto your computer, and to configure device properties and settings.
In information processing, an operation performed by the computer at hand rather than by a remote computer.
A device capable of processing information, storing data, and producing a desired result based on instructions provided.
A menu that is related to the active window or item, accessible by right-clicking the mouse.

In relational database management systems, a logical table created through the specification of one or more relational operations on one or more tables. A view is equivalent to a divided relation in the relational model.
To provide or give.
A portion of a software window bounded by and separated from other portions by vertical or horizontal bars and having a separate function.

An (API) that is provided as part of Microsoft Windows. CryptoAPI provides a set of functions that allow applications to encrypt or digitally sign data in a flexible manner while providing protection for the user's sensitive private key data. Actual cryptographic operations are performed by independent modules known as (CSPs).
A Microsoft Windows multimedia file format for sound and videos that uses the Microsoft Resource Interchange File Format (RIFF) specification.
A visual effect that imparts a quality of translucency to windows.
The distance or period of time between a specified start point and a specified end point. For example, the length of an audio or video clip is usually measured in minutes and seconds.
To store frequently used data values in a special memory subsystem for quick access.
To add new text, objects or cells without overwriting existing data.
Pertaining to characters that are evenly slanted to the right or in the direction of text flow.
An action or occurrence to which a program might respond. Examples include state changes, data transfers, key presses, and mouse movements.
A real-time communication session between two or more users, which can involve IM, video, or audio.
An entity that provides goods and/or services to others.
A path to a file on a network that can be a URL or a UNC path and that can contain a reference to a location within the file.
Data that consists of characters representing the words and symbols of human speech.
Any of the devices on a layered communications network that operate on the same protocol level.

To decompress, or pull out, files from a compressed form. When you extract a file, an uncompressed copy of the file is placed in the folder you specify. The original file remains in the compressed folder. Compressed files frequently have a .zip file name extension.
To go back to a previous state by reversing the effects of one or more commands.
A sequence of 25 letters and numbers. To activate some software, you must enter a product key during the activation process.
To write data (typically a file) to a storage medium.
A collection of contact information for particular individuals, groups or organizations.
The smallest amount of disk space that can be allocated to hold a file.
A set of interlinked documents in a hypertext system enter through a home page.
A set of interlinked documents in a hypertext system enter through a home page.
A set of interlinked documents in a hypertext system enter through a home page.
An interactive utility that guides users through a multi-step, infrequently performed task reducing the knowledge required to perform the task compared to alternative UIs.
The approximate location of one or more resources, such as a person, computer, printer, or asset, in a space plan.
A Microsoft computer operating system with a command-line interface that is used to control many internal computer functions, such as running programs and organizing and maintaining files.

A standard international numeric abbreviation for a country or geographical region. A language identifier is a 16-bit value that consists of a primary language identifier and a secondary language identifier.
A type of flowchart that shows the relationship between a business process and the functional units (such as departments) responsible for that process.

A set of keystrokes and instructions recorded and saved as a key combination (such as CTRL + X) or file name. When the macro is used, all of the recorded steps are performed automatically. Macros save time by replacing a series of frequently performed steps with a simple key combination or name.
Memory that is not allocated to any program.
A single- or double-digit number associated with telephone numbers, or email or Web addresses, that enables users to quickly access the numbers or addresses.
A unit of memory measurement that consists of eight bits.
A set of coordinated graphic elements applied to a document, Web page, or across all pages in a Web site.
A message sent to the user or administrator of a system where the recipient may be a human or an automated notification manager.

Broadly, any device that performs arithmetic operations on numbers. Sophisticated calculators can be programmed for certain functions and can store values in memory, but they differ from computers in several ways: they have a fixed set of commands, they do not recognize text, they cannot retrieve values stored in a data file, and they cannot find and use values generated by a program such as a spreadsheet.
An implementation of Domain Name System (DNS) written and ported to most available versions of the UNIX operating system. The Internet Software Consortium maintains the BIND software.
The overall layout or pattern of a document.
A standard Windows control that combines text box and list box functions.
The attributes of a cell in a spreadsheet, such as its being alphabetic or numeric, the number of digits, the use of commas, and the use of currency signs.
A group of settings that affect how a file is printed on the page. Includes paper size and orientation, page margins, headers and footers.
A software component that enables message exchange through a specific transport.
A feature that allows the user to share items such as documents or folders with other devices on a layered communications network that operate on the same protocol level.
A color model that describes color information in terms of the red (R), green (G), and blue (B) intensities that make up the color.
A user’s assessment of how good they think a particular piece of content or product is.
A combination of operators, constants, literal values, functions, and names of fields (columns), controls, and properties that evaluates to a single value.
A data unit of 1024 bytes.
A data unit of 1024 bytes.

To explicitly consent to participate. Typically used in marketing programs and offerings, whereby an action (such as the use of personal information beyond the original, primary purpose for which it was collected) is not undertaken unless an individual explicitly consents. An element of choice.
A device, such as a disk drive, printer, modem, or joystick, that is connected to a computer and is controlled by the computer's microprocessor.
To modify or assemble hardware or software to suit the needs or preferences of the user.
A routable protocol in the TCP/IP protocol suite that is responsible for IP addressing, routing, and the fragmentation and reassembly of IP packets.
A keyword or description used to identify groups of related items.
A software program used to display webpages and to navigate the Internet.
A software program used to display webpages and to navigate the Internet.

A directive to an email program to send a complete copy of a given piece of mail to another individual. The use of cc mail addressing, as opposed to directly addressing the mail to a person, generally implies that the recipient is not required to take any action; the message is for informational purposes only. In a cc directive, the fact that this recipient received the mail is printed in the mail header and is thus known to all other recipients.
Pertaining to a process that is performed by a person, rather than automated.
To eliminate text, a file, or part of a document with the intention of removing the information permanently.
A 16-byte value generated from the unique identifier on a device, the current date and time, and a sequence number that is used to identify a particular device, component, user, or session.

A local area network (LAN) that sends and receives data via radio, infrared optical signaling, or some other technology that does not require a physical connection between individual nodes and the hub. Wireless LANs are often used in office or factory settings where a user must carry a portable computer from place to place.
Any feature in the computer system based on older technology for which compatibility continues to be maintained in other system components.
A limitation or a restriction.
A built-in format that can be applied to a range of data, or to controls and sections in a form or report to change their appearance.
A specific action carried out by a computer in the process of executing a program.
A variety of graphics tablet that uses pressure sensors, rather than the electromagnetics used in more expensive high-resolution tablets, to track the position of a device on its surface.

A group of files that modify Windows features. Package types include service packs, security updates, language packs, and hotfixes. Examples of packages include LanguagePack, Windows Foundation, and FeaturePack.
In the Microsoft WOSA (Windows Open System Architecture) structure, an interface providing a common language for Windows applications to gain access to a database on a network.
The document in which you are working.

A distribution mechanism for frequently-updated content that is aggregated by an RSS reader and delivered or published in a standard XML format where the content is often summarized, with links to a more complete version.

A distribution mechanism for frequently-updated content that is aggregated by an RSS reader and delivered or published in a standard XML format where the content is often summarized, with links to a more complete version.
A person who is part of a group.
Pertaining to time when a person is already scheduled for another task and is not available.
A place where one lives.
An area within the Control Panel that provides accessibility options and settings to help users interact more easily with the computer.
The menu item that opens the About dialog box, which includes the copyright, licensing, and license terms for the product.
A duplicate of a program, a disk, or data, made either for archiving purposes or for safeguarding files.
A cell that contains a formula that refers to another cell. For example, if cell D10 contains the formula =B5, cell D10 is a dependent of cell B5.

Information about a client computer that Network Access Protection (NAP) uses to allow or deny access to a network and which is encapsulated in a statement of health (SoH), which is issued by a system health agent (SHA) on the client computer.
The temporary storage area the computer uses to run programs and store data. Information stored in RAM is temporary and is designed to be erased when the computer is turned off.

The wireless communication technology that conforms to the Bluetooth computing and telecommunications industry specification. This specification describes how mobile phone, landline phones, computers, and mobile devices can easily exchange information by using a short-range wireless connection.
The small, upward-pointing symbol (^) typically found over the 6 key on the top row of a microcomputer keyboard.

A printed circuit board that enables a personal computer to use a peripheral device, such as a CD-ROM drive, modem, or joystick, for which it does not already have the necessary connections, ports, or circuit boards. Commonly, a single adapter card can have more than one adapter on it.

An address for a resource on the Internet that is used by Web browsers to locate Internet resources. An Internet address typically starts with a protocol name, followed by the name of the organization that maintains the site; the suffix identifies the kind of organization it is.
An email message that a user sends to others to invite them to a meeting.
To transmit content such as a message or file through a communications channel.
To transmit content such as a message or file through a communications channel.
To enlarge or reduce the display of an item, such as a drawing or a proportional character font, by adjusting its size proportionally.
To return to the last saved version of a document. Choosing this command tells the application to abandon all changes made in a document since the last time it was saved.
A file that stores messages generated by an application, service, or operating system that are used to track the operations performed.
To insert information created in one program, such as a chart, an equation, an image, a video or a font, into another program or Web page.
To reverse something or change it to its opposite.
An area upon which users can draw multiple shapes, such that the shapes can be moved and resized as a unit.
A collection of compositions or memorabilia of a specific type or for a particular purpose, such as audio recordings, photographs, or documents.
A return to a previous stable condition, as when the contents of a hard disk are restored from a backup after a destructive hard disk error.
To attempt to establish a voice conversation with another person or other people from a phone, computer, or mobile device.
Worksheet data in which rows or columns of detail data are grouped so that you can create summary reports. The outline can summarize either an entire worksheet or a selected portion of it.
A document on the World Wide Web that consists of an HTML file, with associated files for graphics and scripts, in a particular directory on a particular machine (and thus identifiable by an URL).
A document on the World Wide Web that consists of an HTML file, with associated files for graphics and scripts, in a particular directory on a particular machine (and thus identifiable by an URL).
A document on the World Wide Web that consists of an HTML file, with associated files for graphics and scripts, in a particular directory on a particular machine (and thus identifiable by an URL).
A location to which products that have been ordered should be sent.

To check two items, such as words, files, or numeric values, so as to determine whether they are the same or different. In a program, the outcome of a compare operation often determines which of two or more actions is taken next.
A way to arrange data based on value or data type.

A collection of files and folders (sometimes compressed into one file) that duplicates the original file and folder structure of an operating system. It often contains other files added by the OEM or corporation.

For files, information that indicates whether a file is read-only, hidden, ready for archiving (backing up), compressed, or encrypted, and whether the file contents should be indexed for fast file searching.

A security method used by wireless networks. WPA encrypts the information that is sent between computers on a wireless network and authenticates users to help ensure that only authorized people can access the network.
A BIOS developed to enable system-related information, such as information about hardware, to be gathered from computers on a network.
A method of arranging data based on the order of specified information. For example, records sorted by class would list all records within a class before moving to records in the next class.

An entry in either a securable object's discretionary access control list (DACL) or an object's system access control list (SACL). In a DACL, the entry grants or denies permissions to a user or group. In a SACL, the entry specifies which security events to audit for a particular user or group or controls the Windows Integrity Level for the object.
Pertaining to an area restricted to a short distance from a reference point.
The degree of confidentiality of an email message or calendar item, ranging from normal to confidential.
A feature that calculates and displays the number of words, characters, lines, pages and paragraphs in a document.

A representation on the screen of the mouse pointer location. In a document or file, it usually appears as a blinking vertical line to indicate where you can insert text or graphics. In other applications, it can appear as a cross or as an arrow.
A small pop-up window that provides a brief note or label pertaining to the item or control being pointed to.
A set of scenarios that lead to a desired outcome by a customer segment.
A ready-made button that the user can insert into his/her presentation and define hyperlinks for.
A word, symbol, or other group of characters used to identify a file, a storage medium, an element defined in a computer program, or a specific item in a document such as a spreadsheet or a chart.
A series of measures to protect a machine from being infected by a virus.
Any piece of equipment that can be attached physically or wirelessly to a network or computer, for example, printers, keyboards, external disk drives, or other peripheral equipment.
The process of turning data into a stream of bits. Encoding is part of the serialization process that converts data into a stream of ones and zeros.
An effect created by simple, repeating designs such as vertical or horizontal lines.
A postal address at which a person is normally resident.
Interactive or animated content used on the Internet. Active content includes ActiveX controls and web browser add-ons.
The paper that a publication is printed on.

A data structure containing zero or more nodes that are linked together in a hierarchy. If any nodes are present, one node is the root; each node except the root is the child of one and only one other node, and each node has zero or more nodes as children.
A compressed file.
A control that contains other controls.
