A server computer that hosts Web pages and responds to requests from browsers.
To stop communications or a network connection.
A unique and secret identification code similar to a password that is assigned to an authorized user and used to gain access to personal information or assets via an electronic device.
A sample email address used in Microsoft software and Help files for demonstration purposes.
A sample email address used in Microsoft software and Help files for demonstration purposes.
The smallest element used to form the composition of an image on a computer monitor.
The smallest element used to form the composition of an image on a computer monitor.
A credit or title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
To close the operating system in an orderly fashion.

A security feature that helps prevent unauthorized changes to a computer, by asking user for permission or administrator credentials before performing actions that could potentially affect the computer's operation or that change settings that affect multiple users.

A security feature that helps prevent unauthorized changes to a computer, by asking user for permission or administrator credentials before performing actions that could potentially affect the computer's operation or that change settings that affect multiple users.

A portion of a document in which you set certain page formatting options. You create a new section when you want to change such properties as line numbering, number of columns, or headers and footers.
To align objects or text around a point located in the middle of a line, page, or other defined area; in effect, to position items an equal distance from each margin or border.
A Microsoft Web site maintained by the Windows product group for the purpose of providing updates for core Windows components.
A graphics function which calculates computer image effects pixel by pixel allowing control of the lighting, shading and color of each individual pixel.

A property of a replica that indicates which members of the replica set it can synchronize with and which conflict resolution rules apply. Replicas fall into three visibility types: global, local, and anonymous.
A set of intersecting lines or linear elements at right angles to each other.
An artificial language that specifies instructions to be executed on a computer. The term covers a wide spectrum, from binary-coded machine language to high-level languages.
A portion of a line, defined by its beginning and ending points.
The User Interface (UI) element in various communications apps and in contact cards that provides access to a list of previous communication via that app or with a particular contact.
A device used to copy files to recordable CDs and DVDs.
A communications device that converts between digital data from a computer or terminal and analog audio signals that can pass through a standard telephone line.
A preliminary version.
The process of using a tablet pen to create drawings or handwriting.
A gradual progression.
An auxiliary software component that extends or enhances the features of other software.

To configure or create a user, tenant, or other account and enable it with access to one or more services; to perform operations on and apply backend configurations to a device to get it ready for use or ready for a new service; to perform backend operations to get a security service ready for use.
A graphic ad that spans the full width of the page and is normally 120 pixels high.

Data that binds a sender's identity to the information being sent. A digital signature may be bundled with any message, file, or other digitally encoded information, or transmitted separately. Digital signatures are used in public key environments and provide authentication and integrity services.

Data that binds a sender's identity to the information being sent. A digital signature may be bundled with any message, file, or other digitally encoded information, or transmitted separately. Digital signatures are used in public key environments and provide authentication and integrity services.
A structural attribute of a cube that organizes data into levels. For example, a Geography dimension might include the members Country, Region, State or Province, and City.
A clickable UI element designed to look like a tab on a file folder. It allows you to navigate between multiple applications, files, pages, or websites, all available within a single window.​
A typographical symbol, such as a filled or empty circle, diamond, box, or asterisk, used to set off a small block of text or each item in a list.
A power source for a portable device.
To trim the vertical or horizontal edges of an object. Pictures are often cropped to focus attention on a particular area.
To cause a digital recording to be reproduced from any starting point on a device.
Of, pertaining to, or being a connection that uses the public switched telephone network rather than a dedicated circuit or some other type of private network.
An XML-based syndication technology that enables websites to distribute content, such as news headlines and blog posts, efficiently to readers.
An area of storage for objects, data, or their references after a user carries out a Cut or Copy command.
A calculator-style block of keys, usually at the right side of a keyboard, that can be used to enter numbers.

One of a number of separately printed parts of an oversized publication, such as a banner or poster, that cannot be printed as a single sheet. Separate tiles can be assembled to recreate the whole publication.

A series of items arranged vertically within some type of framework--for example, a continuous series of cells running from top to bottom in a spreadsheet, a set of lines of specified width on a printed page, a vertical line of pixels on a video screen, or a set of values aligned vertically in a table or matrix.
A path through which information passes between two computers or devices.
To transfer into a store or storage location.

To prepare a disk for use by organizing its storage space into a collection of data "compartments", each of which can be located by the operating system so that data can be sorted and retrieved. When a previously used disk is formatted, any preexisting information on it is lost.
A presence status the user can select, while signed in, to make it appear to other users that he or she is currently willing to be contacted.
Any token that a program can use to identify and access an object such as a device, a file, a window, or a dialog box.
To touch an item once with the tablet pen and then lift the pen quickly.
To retain a physical representation of (data or instructions) that enables them to be subsequently retrieved.
A person who uses products such as devices, services, or applications.
Text that does not fit within a text box. The text is hidden until it can be flowed into a new text box, or until the text box it overflows is resized to include it.
A small part, amount, or proportion of something.
Information about the properties or structure of data that is not part of the values the data contains.
A class of computer programs in which one or more users interact with the computer as a form of entertainment.
A program that is used on a Web page to count the number of times that the Web page was accessed.
A tag or string affixed to an item to provide identifying or descriptive information.
To ask someone to engage in an instant conversation.
A shape on a stencil that you use repeatedly to create drawings.
Engaging in fraud or deceptive.
The direction a publication will be printed on a sheet of paper. You can choose either portrait, which is the taller-than-wide orientation, or landscape, which is the wider-than-tall orientation.
Text, graphics, and any associated annotations captured by using Snipping Tool.
A Windows tool that assists consumers in moving their data (documents and settings) to the new environment.
A filter effect in Windows Movie Maker.
In windowing environments, such as the Apple Macintosh and Microsoft Windows, an on-screen window (enclosed work area) in which the user can create, view, or work on a document.
In a spreadsheet program, a file containing a number of related worksheets.
To programmatically disguise content to hide its substance.
A tab in Windows Media Player that enables the user to view the digital media item that is currently playing.
An image-bearing surface such as a single page or multi-page of text or picture that is passed through a scanner and has become a computer file.
The loudness of an audio signal.

A set of technologies in the Microsoft .NET Framework for building Web applications and XML Web services. ASP.NET pages execute on the server and generate markup (such as HTML, WML, or XML) that is sent to a desktop or mobile browser. ASP.NET pages use a compiled, event-driven programming model that improves performance and enables the separation of application logic and user interface. ASP.NET pages and XML Web services files created using ASP.NET contain server-side (rather than client-side) logic written in Visual Basic .NET, C# .NET, or any .NET-compatible language. Web applications and XML Web services take advantage of the features of the common language runtime, such as type safety, inheritance, language interoperability, versioning, and integrated security.
To confirm either that a result is correct or that a procedure or sequence of operations has been performed.
A set of instructions that a computer or device uses to perform a specific task, such as word processing, accounting, or data management.
A set of instructions that a computer or device uses to perform a specific task, such as word processing, accounting, or data management.

An area of storage on a hard disk. A volume is formatted by using a file system, such as NTFS, and has a drive letter assigned to it. A single hard disk can have multiple volumes. Some volumes can span multiple hard disks.
A tag that closes an element: </>. An end tag follows the syntax </Name>, where Name matches the element name declared in the start tag.
A group of related fields (columns) of information treated as a unit and arranged in a horizontal line in a table or spreadsheet.
A group of related fields (columns) of information treated as a unit and arranged in a horizontal line in a table or spreadsheet.

A hard disk that contains a small amount of solid-state nonvolatile memory which, when used as a cache, can realize significant benefits such as faster booting, extended battery life, and a more rugged PC.

The bar that contains the 'Start' button and appears by default at the bottom of the desktop. You can click the taskbar buttons to switch between programs. You can also hide the taskbar, move it to the sides or top of the desktop, and customize it in other ways.
In an operating system, the overall structure in which files are named, stored, and organized. NTFS, FAT, and FAT32 are types of file systems.
Pertaining to an item that is only visible to an owner, member or other privileged individual.
An input device that consists of individual keys and that is used to convey information from the user to a computer or data communication circuit.
An input device that consists of individual keys and that is used to convey information from the user to a computer or data communication circuit.
A record of synthetic, successive still images that produce an illusion of movement when played back.
A visual design surface.
Pertaining to the state of a control in which normal functionality is not available to a user.
Pertaining to the state of a control in which normal functionality is not available to a user.
A logical connection created between two hosts to exchange data.
A string of characters entered by a user to verify his or her identity to a network or to a local computer, device, or client, or to sign in to an account, app, and so on.
To move an item on the screen (1) by touching the item on a screen and then sliding the finger across the screen or (2) by pressing and holding down the left mouse button while moving the mouse.
Visual impairment that results in great reduction in vision capabilities and that cannot be aided by glasses or contact lenses. It could, however, be aided by special devices.
A device that sends, or routes, information between two networks (for example, between a home network and the Internet).

A collection of rules and data specific to a language and a geographic area. Locales include information on sorting rules, date and time formatting, numeric and monetary conventions, and character classification.
To output data and database objects to another database, spreadsheet, or file format so another database, application, or program can use the data or database objects.
A portable computer that allows you to write on or interact with the screen.
A portable computer that allows you to write on or interact with the screen.
Any significant occurrence in the system or an application that requires a user to be notified or an entry to be added to a log.
Capable of producing successful results.
Pertaining to an application on a local server or client computer, which usually hosts users for business/commercial usage.

A horizontal window at the bottom of a parent window in which an application can display various kinds of status information. The status bar can be divided into parts to display more than one type of information.
In word processors and other applications, the feature that formats a document for printing but displays it on the video monitor rather than sending it directly to the printer.
A graphic that indicates follow-up action is required, or otherwise identifies an important item.
A World Wide Web Consortium specification that describes the structure of dynamic HTML and XML documents in a way that allows them to be manipulated through a Web browser.
To include an external document, a file, or an executable program with a message.
To remove the data or settings currently present on an entity.
To suppress the sound produced by a device or application.

A graphic file format that is supported by some World Wide Web browsers. PNG supports variable transparency of images (alpha channels) and control of image brightness on different computers (gamma correction). PNG files are compressed bitmaps.
Strength exerted; might.
To add a check to a check box to specify a desired feature or option.
A device that is added to the base computer system to increase functionality, such as audio, networking, graphics, or SCSI controller.
A Microsoft Web site that provides customers with access to a database of articles written by Microsoft Support professionals.

A unique set of letters or numbers that identifies a wireless network. For a computer or device to connect to a wireless network, it must supply that network’s SSID. An SSID can be up to 32 characters.

A unique set of letters or numbers that identifies a wireless network. For a computer or device to connect to a wireless network, it must supply that network’s SSID. An SSID can be up to 32 characters.
A message that appears in a newsgroup, public folder, or other forum, such as Facebook or Twitter, accessible by a number of individuals.
The meaning of data as it is intended to be interpreted by people.
To safeguard a resource from attack or loss.
Pertaining to a formatting style in which characters are crossed out by horizontal line.
A feature that notifies a user when there is a change to posted content, workflow status, or when other user-defined criteria are met.
A non-printing line or point that can be used to help position or align objects or text.
A language used to address parts of an XML document. XPath also provides basic facilities for manipulation of strings, numbers, and Boolean values.
The process of reconciling the differences between data stored in one location and a copy of the same data stored in another location.
The process of reconciling the differences between data stored in one location and a copy of the same data stored in another location.
The process of recording actions that take place on a computer, network, or system.
A connection between an element in a hypertext document, such as a word, phrase, symbol, or image, and a different element in the document or in another location, a webpage, file, or script.
A table, chart, graphic, equation, or other form of information.
A part of a form, report, or data access page such as a header, footer, or detail section.

A display format, like that of Windows, that represents a program's functions with graphic images such as buttons and icons. GUIs enable a user to perform operations and make choices by pointing and clicking with a mouse.
The portion of the email address that appears to the left of the @ symbol.
One or more ranges of cells that you designate to print when you don't want to print the entire worksheet. If a worksheet includes a print area, only the print area is printed.
To make a change to existing content such as a file, document, or post.
A new type of ScreenTip that is larger and can contain more detailed information, including graphics.
Of, pertaining to, or characterized by non-capital letters.
Information, such as name, phone number, email address, or address, that is used to contact someone.
Information, such as name, phone number, email address, or address, that is used to contact someone.
Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of an action or operation that takes place based on whether or not a certain condition is true.
The permission setting that permits a person or domain to add the user to contact lists, see the user's status, or send instant messages to the user.
The person in charge of managing a computer. The administrator is responsible for installing software, assigning passwords, and managing files.
The stylistic attributes of a font — such as bold, italic, and underline.
The set of rules on a computer and a portable device that allow digital media files and other information to be synchronized.

The primary access protocol for Active Directory. LDAP is an industry-standard protocol, established by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF), that allows users to query and update information in a directory service. Active Directory supports both LDAP version 2 and LDAP version 3.
A feature in Windows that allows users to access and manage printers, multi-function printers, digital cameras and scanners.
To prevent another user from initiating a conversation and from viewing your presence or other information, such as your personal information.
A list in which each item or block of text is preceded by a bullet.
The temporary storage place on Windows where deleted files are transferred and remain until manually emptied and files are permanently deleted, which allows users to retrieve files until that point.
A field size or data type that can hold positive integer numbers ranging from 0 to 255.

An application that runs on a Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) managed device. The agent application is the object of management activities. A computer running SNMP agent software is also sometimes referred to as an agent.
An optical storage medium for digital data.
A personal or work-related project, assignment, or errand to be tracked through to completion.
A secondary window that allows users to perform a command, asks users a question, or provides users with information or progress feedback.
A rectangular area on a computer screen in which programs and content appear.
A network status that indicates a client is not connected to a server.
To retrieve a writable copy of a file or project from a source repository. This locks the file for editing to prevent others from overwriting or editing it inadvertently.
Add-in software that provides partially localized user interfaces for particular computer programs in languages not supported by localized versions of those programs.
Add-in software that provides partially localized user interfaces for particular computer programs in languages not supported by localized versions of those programs.

A minimum hardware configuration of a computer (typically relates to CPU speed and type, size of RAM, free space on hard disk, and presence of other devices such as sound card, CD-ROM, etc.) needed to run a software program on it.
A number that is not a whole number, such as ½ (vulgar fraction) or 0.5 (decimal fraction), formed by dividing one quantity into another.
A file containing digitized audio, such as voice or music.
A file containing digitized audio, such as voice or music.
The command interpreter that is used to pass commands to the operating system.
A device on which images generated by the computer's video adapter are displayed.

A group of one or more COM objects in a process. A COM object lives in exactly one apartment, in the sense that its methods can legally be directly called only by a thread that belongs to that apartment. Any other thread that wants to call the object must go through a proxy.

A data type that stores a signed, exact numeric value described as the number of digits appearing before and after the decimal point, with a maximum of 29 total digits. All possible digits cannot be represented if you are using the maximum number of digits.
The process of rewriting parts of a file to contiguous sectors on a hard disk to increase the speed of access and retrieval.

A small piece of code that can be transported over the Internet and executed on the recipient's machine. The term is especially used to refer to such programs as they are embedded in line as objects in HTML documents on the World Wide Web.
The condition of a field, record, recordset, or database that makes it read-only to all users except the user currently modifying it.
Information such as audio, video, images, or text that is contained in a digital media file or stream.
A message placed in a mass medium (and usually paid for by the advertiser) to persuade targeted customers or prospects.

The basic element that holds information in Outlook (similar to a file in other programs). Items include email messages, appointments, contacts, tasks, journal entries, notes, posted items, and documents.
The structure or organization of data in a file.
The structure or organization of data in a file.
An organization with more than 1000 employees and more than 500 personal computers.

A font display technology that dramatically improves font display resolution so that letters on the computer screen appear smooth, not jagged. ClearType dramatically improves the readability of text on color LCD monitors with a digital interface, such as those found in laptops and high-quality flat-panel desktop displays.

A precompiled collection of SQL statements and optional control-of-flow statements stored under a name and processed as a unit. They are stored in an SQL database and can be run with one call from an application.
A set of software functionality designed to solve a specific problem or to provide a new functionality to the user.
Files that are used to help detect harmful or unwanted software and to prevent it from installing or running on your computer.

A user interface element that provides users with a quick and easy way to navigate across a large group of opened Web pages by providing the user with a visual representation of all of the opened thumbnails. Through this visualization, the user can easily spot and select a desired thumbnail.
The speed at which binary digits are transmitted.
To change a program in order to be able to run it on a different platform.
A feature that allows you to set up your computer so that when you insert a device or media, it will play automatically and you won't have to select your preferences every time.
Personal configurations of a program or operating system.
A text file containing code to apply semantics such as page layout specifications to published content.
A serial communications port used to connect a device, such as a modem, printer, or mobile device, to a computer.
A database object that stores data in records (rows) and fields (columns). The data is usually about a particular category of things, such as employees or orders.
A type of CD on which files can be copied, erased, and replaced.
The legal agreement between Microsoft and the user, with regard to the terms of use and transfer of software.
For local area networks (LANs), a device that is connected to the network and is capable of communicating with other network devices.
A function of some Web browsers that allows users to surf and view multiple pages by loading Web sites into sections (or tabs) of one page, rather than multiple pages.
Of or pertaining to documents, data, software, or hardware that existed prior to a certain time.
A rectangular array of pixels applied to a visual object.
Any ink that you add to a file that is not recognized as handwriting.
The structure or appearance of a unit of data, such as a field, or text in a message body.
A natural number, zero, or the negative of a natural number.
To transfer a copy of a file from a local computer to a remote computer by means of a modem or network.
For a computer system, to be in an inactive state, but not shut off. When the computer is switched back on, the desktop is restored exactly as it was.
A field you can create. A custom field can be a blank, combination, or formula field.
To start or reset a computer by turning the power on, by pressing a reset button on the computer case, or by issuing a software command to restart.
A protocol that establishes the security association and shared keys necessary for computers to communicate by using Internet Protocol security (IPsec).
To prevent the writing (recording) of information, usually on a disk.
A filter effect in Windows Movie Maker.
A graphic element on a drawing that is associated with data.
To close software, such as a program or application.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
A collection of masters associated with a particular Visio drawing type, or template. By default, stencils that open with a template are docked on the left side of the drawing window.

The feature in Internet Explorer that remembers the information you have typed into the Address bar, web forms, or password fields, and which automatically fills in that information if you start to type the same thing again later.
A pre-released version of a product that is sent to customers and partners for evaluation and feedback.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
A directory or folder made available to users over the network.
The process of confirming that data passing into the system is correct and complies with predefined rules, definitions, or parameters.
Any fixed or removable objects that store computer data. Examples include hard disks, floppy disks, tapes, and compact discs.
In the printing and display of characters on the screen, an imaginary horizontal line with which the base of each character, excluding descenders, is aligned.
A group of devices that communicate either wirelessly or via a physical connection.
An item on the Control Panel.
A profile that contains the data needed for translating the values of a color gamut. This data includes information about color, hue, saturation, and brightness.

A set of members in a dimension hierarchy such that all members of the set are at the same distance from the root of the hierarchy. For example, a time hierarchy may contain the levels Year, Month, and Day.
One or more identifying lines printed at the top of a page. A header may contain a page number, a date, the author's name, and the document title, the name of chapter.
One or more identifying lines printed at the top of a page. A header may contain a page number, a date, the author's name, and the document title, the name of chapter.

The UI element that initiates the process of seeking a particular file or specific data. A search is carried out by a program through comparison or calculation to determine whether a match to some pattern exists or whether some other criteria have been met.
A person who is allowed to view and read content.
Displacement of the left or right edge of a block of text in relation to the margin or to other blocks of text.
Displacement of the left or right edge of a block of text in relation to the margin or to other blocks of text.
A user-defined shortcut to the most commonly used forms, reports, websites, etc.
Pertaining to the delivery of information that combines different content formats, such as video, audio, still images, graphics, animation, and text.
A feature in email programs that allows a user to send a copy of an email message to a recipient without notifying other recipients that this was done.
In DNS, a part of a DNS domain name that represents a node in the domain namespace tree.
A list of options from which a user can choose.
A pointed input device that comes with a mobile device or tablet PC, and is used to navigate through applications and to input information.
An option on Windows Parental Control that, if selected, creates logs of all the actions performed by a user on the computer.
A personal record of experiences, occurrences or proceedings, like a Baby Book or Life Book.
One of many sequential images that make up video or animation.
A method of exchanging messages and computer files over a network that does not require the sender and recipient to be online at the same time.
An object (such as a customer, item, or employee) that shares a set of defined attributes or characteristics, and that is used to manage rules for data.
A quick movement of a finger or pen on a screen that the computer interprets as a command, rather than as a mouse movement, writing, or drawing.
Pertaining to a file format that does not allow for VBA code. Office 12 default file formats are macro-free. Examples of file extensions for macro-free formats are .docx, .pptx, .xlsx.
As one aspect of a KPI, the desired level of performance with respect to a specific business goal or strategy. Actual values are evaluated against the target to determine KPI score and status.
To publish or write entries for a blog.

The ability to interpret vocal commands or convert spoken words into computer-readable text. Speech recognition programs enable you to control an application or enter text by speaking into a microphone, rather than by using a keyboard.
To update displayed information with current data.
To grant a person, computer process, or device access to certain information, services or functionality.
To remove oneself as a recipient on a mailing list.
A representation of concepts such as facts or instructions in a formalized manner, suitable for communication, interpretation or processing.
A line that separates groups of controls (on a surface) or commands (on a menu).
A command button used in a toolbar (or status bar).
A database object that prints information formatted and organized according to your specifications.
One or more lines of text in the bottom margin area of a page. A footer may contain elements such as the page number, the name of the file, or the date.
A string of text written in the command language and passed to the command interpreter for execution.
A short piece of content that is informative but not essential.
When referring to software, to remove program files and folders from the hard disk and remove related data from the registry so the software or solution is no longer available.
To do over again.
The area on the right side of the Windows taskbar. It contains shortcuts to programs and important status information.
To halt a process temporarily.
A physical item for sale or purchase or available for license.
A box formed by the intersection of a row and a column in a worksheet or a table, in which you enter information.
The act of entering and editing text with a word processor.
To change the size of an element on the screen.
The display of information from a given perspective or location.
A document describing a company's position on privacy, detailing what information it collects, with whom the data is shared, and how users can control the use of their personal information.
Data from a table, form, query, view, or stored procedure, displayed in a row-and-column format.
To put new data in the place of other data, usually after conducting a search for the data to be replaced. Text-based applications such as word processors typically include Find and Replace commands.
Relating to frequencies within the range of perception by the human ear - from about 15 to 20,000 hertz (cycles per second).
A type of markup in markup languages. A start tag is the starting element of a tag pair which contains metainformation about some part of the text.
A button that opens Sync Center.
The width-to-height ratio of a video or still image, or of the screen on which an image is displayed.
A feature of a computer or operating system that allows it to run programs written for a different system.
A file that contains audio, video, or script data.
Malware that replicates, commonly by infecting other files in the system, thus allowing the execution of the malware code and its propagation when those files are activated.
A wireless implementation and the second generation of WPA security that is based on the final IEEE 802.11i amendment to the 802.11 standard.
Personal Area Networks (PAN) that communicate directly between one or more Bluetooth-enabled computers or devices.
To cause an application to display information on a computer or device screen.
An individual who sends an electronic message.
Settings that allow the administrator to control the collection, use, and distribution of personal data.

A pane that displays details about an item selected in another portion of the user interface. For example, in Microsoft Management Console (MMC), the details pane is the right pane that displays details for the selected item in the console tree.
A form contained within another form or a report.
To enlarge a selected portion of a graphical image or document to fill a window or the screen.
To enlarge a selected portion of a graphical image or document to fill a window or the screen.

A Regional and Language Options setting that specifies the default code pages and associated bitmap font files for a specific computer that affects all of that computer's users. The default code pages and fonts enable a non-Unicode application written for one operating system language version to run correctly on another operating system language version.
A monitoring option in real-time spyware protection that monitors various types and areas of software activity on your computer.

A row, column, or block of buttons or icons, usually displayed across the top of the screen, that represent tasks or commands within the program. The toolbar buttons provide shortcuts to common tasks frequently accessed from the menus.
A graphic or diagram that displays data or the relationships between sets of data in pictorial rather than numeric form.
A list that can be opened to reveal all choices for a given field.
A category of objects that share a common set of characteristics.
A quantity assigned to an element such as a variable, symbol, or label.
To store data in such a way that it can be retrieved later by the same security support component, and only by that security support component.
To associate a flag with a message or other item.
Erroneous or unrecognizable because of a flaw in reasoning or an error in input. Invalid results, for example, might occur if the logic in a program is faulty.
A menu item in Internet Explorer that turns on the tool for Tablet PC users that allows the user to move the content of the page up and down, like a mouse scroll wheel.
The activities and actions performed by customer service representatives to assist customers.
A unit of work that is represented to users in the form of buttons, links, and menu items.
To move an item to a higher level within a structure.
The / character.

The server name, user name, password, and email address used to connect to an email service. You create the email account using information provided by your mail administrator or Internet service provider (ISP).
To create a user session for an Internet account.
A single media file, including art, sound, animation, or movies.
To insert content, such as text or a graphic, that has been cut or copied from one document into a different location in the same or a different document.
A program that creates files or makes changes to existing files.
A program that creates files or makes changes to existing files.
To identify with a label.
To make a duplicate copy of a program, a disk, or data.

Pertaining to keyboard settings, document views, user interface objects, and languages for which text is displayed in a left-to-right direction. English and most other European languages are left-to-right languages.
A control in Windows that enables the user to choose one option from a list of possibilities.
A movable piece on a device that is pressed to activate some function.
A view of a document as it will appear when you print it.
A set of graphics, text, and colors for defining different levels of performance when comparing an actual value and a target value within a KPI.
A UI command used to switch between accounts on a device.
The overall plan or design of a document system.
In computer design, the arrangement of circuits and other components of the system.
Pertaining to characters that are formatted to appear darker and heavier than the surrounding text.

The electronic components that generate the video signal sent through a cable to a video display. The video adapter is usually located on the computer's main system board or on an expansion board, but it is sometimes built into the terminal.

The electronic components that generate the video signal sent through a cable to a video display. The video adapter is usually located on the computer's main system board or on an expansion board, but it is sometimes built into the terminal.

Part of the integrated Routing and Remote Access service that provides remote networking for telecommuters, mobile workers, and system administrators who monitor and manage servers at multiple branch offices. Users can use Network Connections to dial in to remotely access their networks for services such as file and printer sharing, electronic mail, scheduling, and SQL database access.
A connection between the user's device and a server that provides access to the Internet, typically through an Internet service provider.
A sequence of shades ranging from black through white, used in computer graphics to add detail to images or to represent a color image on a monochrome output device.
To scan a database, a list of files, or the Internet, either for a particular item or for anything that seems to be of interest.
Light that is beyond red in the color spectrum. While the light is not visible to the human eye, infrared transmitters and receivers can send and receive infrared signals.

A feature that enables records managers to create and manage entries to a “Holds list” such that any document, image, or webpage on that list cannot be deleted, modified, or allowed to expire until the item is removed from the list. The feature is typically used for items that are subject to events such as litigation, audits, or investigations.
A Control Panel feature that is used to set restrictions on what traffic is allowed to enter your network from the Internet.
A utility that enables the user to locate and open files and folders.
A utility that enables the user to locate and open files and folders.
Any of the set of words that comprises a given programming language or set of operating-system routines.
The location where text or graphics will be inserted. Also used for text box controls to indicate input focus.
The status applied to blocks of time in a user's Calendar to indicate that the user will be away.
The color against which characters and graphics are displayed.
Pertaining to items that occur repeatedly. For example, an appointment or task that occurs on a regular basis, such as a weekly status meeting or a monthly haircut, can be designated as recurring.
A security feature that monitors programs on a computer to determine if they use system memory safely.
A security feature that monitors programs on a computer to determine if they use system memory safely.
The consistent positioning of text, graphics, and other objects.
The degree to which a product or service executes its specified function.

On a keyboard, the combination of a plastic keycap, a tension mechanism that suspends the keycap but allows it to be pressed down, and an electronic mechanism that records the key press and key release.
An individual’s ability to view, modify, and contest the accuracy and completeness of PII collected about him/her, and in regards to his/her privacy.
An outlined container that displays a markup element, such as a comment or revision, in the margin of a document.
To activate an application program (especially on the Macintosh) from the operating system's user interface.
The original plan for a project, a work package, or an activity.
Header and footer information, or header information only, which encapsulates or precedes document data for transport.
In a DVD or a video, a portion of a title, such as a scene or sequence. A title can contain one or more chapters.
The smallest executable entity within a programming language.
A compact disc containing audio information (as opposed to a CD-ROM containing data and files).
A customer service issue or problem reported by a customer and the activities that customer service representatives use to resolve it.
A customer service issue or problem reported by a customer and the activities that customer service representatives use to resolve it.
A named storage area on a device that contains files and other folders.
The button that directs the user to the Home section of an application.
To convert encrypted content back into its original form.
A predefined combination of grouped and sorted messages in table view.
To arrange to receive a product or use a service regularly.
To make a record, file, or other data available in the system.
A character that separates items in a list.
A collective of people who interact through or use online resources.
In Windows-based systems, a unique value that identifies a user, group, or computer account within an enterprise. Every account is issued a SID when it is created.
A camera for use with a computer to transmit a video picture.
To find.
A digital interface specification for delivering digital content and connecting consumer electronic devices.

A person, inside or outside your organization, for whom you have created an entry where you can save several types of information, such as street and email addresses, telephone and fax numbers, and Web page URLs.
The device that communicates between your software program and your printer.
Microsoft's antimalware solution that provides next generation protection for desktops, portable computers, and servers.
A tool that lets you enter complex characters and symbols, such as those used in East Asian written languages, using a standard keyboard.
Pertaining to keyboard settings, document views, user interface objects, languages, etc. for which text is displayed in a right-to-left direction.
Pertaining to keyboard settings, document views, user interface objects, languages, etc. for which text is displayed in a right-to-left direction.
The information about a computer that's derived from the System Information program.
A role that controls how permissions are set and can grant permissions to others.
A set of entities working together to accomplish a task.
A networking standard that uses cables to provide network access. Ethernet is the most widely installed technology for connecting computers.

A character-encoding standard developed by the Unicode Consortium that represents almost all of the written languages of the world. The Unicode character repertoire has multiple representation forms, including UTF-8, UTF-16, and UTF-32. Most Windows interfaces use the UTF-16 form.

A type of display that uses a liquid compound having a polar molecular structure, sandwiched between two transparent electrodes. When an electric field is applied, the molecules align with the field, forming a crystalline arrangement that polarizes the light passing through it. A polarized filter laminated over the electrodes blocks polarized light. In this way, a grid of electrodes can selectively "turn on" a cell, or a pixel, containing the liquid crystal material, turning it dark.
A keyboard key that sends the escape (ESC) character to the computer. Often this key moves the user back one level in the menu structure or exits the program.
A customer's right to control how and to what extent their personal information is collected and used and with whom it is shared.
A feature that identifies people using computers near you so that you can use features and programs that use peer-to-peer technology.
Any device that changes electrical signals or computer data from one form to another. For example, an analog-to-digital converter translates analog signals to digital signals.

A file containing information that the user either requires or will find informative and that might not have been included in the documentation. Readme files are placed on disk in plain-text form (without extraneous or program-specific characters) so that they can be read easily be a variety of word processing programs.

A file containing information that the user either requires or will find informative and that might not have been included in the documentation. Readme files are placed on disk in plain-text form (without extraneous or program-specific characters) so that they can be read easily be a variety of word processing programs.
The amount of light that is emitted by a computer monitor or picture displayed on the monitor.

In an environment capable of displaying multiple on-screen windows, any window other than the one currently being used for work. An inactive window can be partially or entirely hidden behind another window, and it remains inactive until the user selects it.
A database query and programming language widely used for accessing, querying, updating, and managing data in relational database systems.
To duplicate data and reproduce it in another part of a document, in a different file or memory location, or in a different medium.
The consistent vertical positioning of text, graphics, and other objects.
The pairing of two or more actions that are performed together as a single action; the action succeeds or fails as a whole.
To displace the left or right edge of a text item, such as a block or a line, relative to the margin or to another text item.
To place a file or project back in a source repository. This releases the lock for editing and enables other users to view the updated file or check out the file.
The practice of recording, classifying, summarizing, and reporting the financial consequences of accounting events.
The processor in an imagesetter or desktop printer that interprets the commands sent by a printer driver and converts them to a raster or bitmap grid to mark the paper or film.
Software that is used to compress or decompress a digital media file.
A note alongside the main text that contains interesting or useful information.
The blank space outside the printing area on a page.
To make a resource, such as a form, view, or device, available over a network.
A miniature version of an image that is often used for quick browsing through multiple images.
The top level of a business hierarchy.
An independent section on a webpage. Each frame is actually a separate webpage and can have its own scrollbars.
A spreadsheet that contains information about a shape; for example, its dimensions, angle, and center of rotation and the styles that determine the shape's appearance.
Tasks that a user is permitted to perform on a computer system or domain.
A series of instructions that is repeated a fixed number of times or until a terminating condition is reached.

A piece of handheld equipment such as a portable music or video player, PDA (personal digital assistant), mobile phone, tablet or warehouse device that works on its own but can also be connected to a computer.

A piece of handheld equipment such as a portable music or video player, PDA (personal digital assistant), mobile phone, tablet or warehouse device that works on its own but can also be connected to a computer.
A modular unit of code that acts as part of a larger system or structure.
Information that includes identification and proof of identification that is used to gain access to local and network resources.
Information that includes identification and proof of identification that is used to gain access to local and network resources.
Information that includes identification and proof of identification that is used to gain access to local and network resources.
The technology that is based on the Component Object Model (COM) that enables interoperability among ActiveX components, including OLE components. Formerly referred to as OLE Automation.

An encryption algorithm that uses a 56-bit key and maps a 64-bit input block to a 64-bit output block. The key appears to be a 64-bit key, but one bit in each of the eight bytes is used for odd parity, resulting in 56 bits of usable key.
Pertaining to a message sent in real time through a network to a private chat area.
An external file included with a message.
An area of the window that displays a limited view of search results or other content.
In a graphical user interface such as Windows, a pattern or picture in the screen background that can be chosen by the user.

A member of the TCP/IP suite of protocols, used to copy files between two computers on the Internet. Both computers must support their respective FTP roles: one must be an FTP client and the other an FTP server.
A collection of binaries that can be installed on top of the core product and enables users to select a preferred language so that the user interface and Help files appear in that preferred language.

A common programming interface to the lower-level system area network (SAN) implementations, developed by Microsoft. WSD sits underneath the standard WinSock application programming interface (API), but bypasses the kernel networking layers to talk directly to the SAN hardware. Because WSD sits underneath the existing WinSock API, IT departments can deploy applications in a SAN environment without modifying the applications.
A sequence of declarations and statements that are executed as a unit.

An electronic system of transmitting transient images of fixed or moving objects together with sound through space by an apparatus that converts light and sound into electrical waves and reconverts them into visible light rays and audible sound.

An electronic system of transmitting transient images of fixed or moving objects together with sound through space by an apparatus that converts light and sound into electrical waves and reconverts them into visible light rays and audible sound.
A user dictionary that contains a list of words not in the application dictionary that an author wants the spelling checker to accept as correct.
A classification for grouping content by user-defined criteria such as page contents, file types, or a similar distinction.
A button on the address bar that enables the user to navigate to the specified location (such as a folder path or web address).
A person whose work or profession is management.
A set of formatting characteristics that you can apply to text, tables, and lists in your document to quickly change their appearance.
A name that uniquely identifies a server computer on a network.
To hold back elements or modify the appearance of an existing list or data set in order to view a specific subset of the data.

An 8-byte, fixed-point data type that is useful for calculations involving money or for fixed-point calculations in which accuracy is extremely important. The Currency data type is used to store numbers with up to 15 digits to the left of the decimal point and 4 digits to the right. The type-declaration character in Microsoft© Visual Basic© is an at sign (@). Currency can range from -922,337,203,685,477.5808 to 922,337,203,685,477.5807.

A form of storage characterized by high capacity (roughly 650 MB) and the use of laser optics rather than magnetic means for reading data. Optical disk storage commonly used for audio, video, and computer data. DVDs range in capacity from 4.7 GB to 17 GB, and can store significantly more than a CD-ROM.
The accuracy of data and its conformity to its expected value, especially after being transmitted or processed.
An image that has been captured electronically with a digital camera or scanner.
An image that has been captured electronically with a digital camera or scanner.
An inability to perform two or more activities because they have been scheduled to occur during the same time period and with the same resource or resources.
In a graphical user interface such as Windows, a pattern or picture in the screen background that can be chosen by the user.
In a graphical user interface such as Windows, a pattern or picture in the screen background that can be chosen by the user.
In a graphical user interface such as Windows, a pattern or picture in the screen background that can be chosen by the user.
To attach a label to.
To wait for incoming traffic, calls or connection requests on a port.
To be unresponsive.

An application of the Standard Generalized Markup Language that uses tags to mark elements, such as text and graphics, in a document to indicate how Web browsers should display these elements to the user and should respond to user actions.
A copy of a master, which you create by dragging the master from a stencil to a drawing.
To activate something making it available for use.
A visual display of data in a dashboard that can be coordinated with other report views by using filters.
A color that is mixed with black. A 10-percent shade is one part of the original color and nine parts black.
The feature of partial control parents get over the accounts and devices of their children helping them supervise how their children behave online and letting them restrict what their children see.
The naming convention for disk drives or partitions on most computers, consisting of an alphabetical letter followed by a colon.
A sequence of words or other text used to gain access to a network, program, or data. A passphrase is generally longer for added security.
A typographical unit of measure that is equal to one sixth of an inch.
A configuration parameter that controls the behavior of a service, application, feature, function, or a run-time environment.
A route through a structured collection of information, as in a database, a program, or files stored on disk.
The area in each row of a database table that stores the data value for some attribute of the object modeled by the table.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
A menu choice or remote button that offers access to the user's video library.

A small, Internet Protocol (IP)-based network. It is usually used for short-range, ad-hoc communication between devices and computers. A PAN may also be used to enable connectivity to a larger Local Area Network (LAN), Wide-Area Network (WAN), or the Internet. Windows XP supports the Bluetooth PAN service so you can create Personal Area Networks using Bluetooth.

Authorization to perform operations associated with a specific shared resource, such as a file, directory, or printer and that must be granted by the system administrator to individual user accounts or administrative groups.

Authorization to perform operations associated with a specific shared resource, such as a file, directory, or printer and that must be granted by the system administrator to individual user accounts or administrative groups.
A person who is involved in the creation of content. For example editors, technical reviewers and subject matter experts are contributors.
The amount of space from the bottom of one line of text to the bottom of the next line.
A network within an organization that uses Internet technologies and protocols, but is available only to certain people, such as employees of a company.
The horizontal arrangement of cells in a table or spreadsheet.
A summary of one's academic and work history, usually submitted with a job application.
Software that fulfills the deliberately harmful intent of an attacker when run.
Software that fulfills the deliberately harmful intent of an attacker when run.
To end an application's relationship with an open file so that the application will no longer be able to access the file without opening it again.
A complete Web site stored in a named subdirectory of the top-level Web site.
A symbol selected to designate a specific currency.
On a disk or other direct-access storage device, a continuous block of storage space reserved by the operating system for a particular file or program.
The writing or drawing strokes that you make with your stylus or fingers.
To compress into an archive.
The field that contains a contact's mobile phone number.
The ? character, used as a punctuation mark or wildcard character.
A string that identifies a user so that the user can receive Internet email and typically consists of an account name, followed by the @ (at) symbol, a host name, and a domain name.
A set of conditions that hold back elements or modify the appearance of an existing list or data set in order to view a specific subset of the data.
A set of conditions that hold back elements or modify the appearance of an existing list or data set in order to view a specific subset of the data.
To send a received content either modified or in its entirety, to a new recipient.
A client program or control that receives digital media content streamed from a server or played from local files. Windows Media Player is an example of a player.
The portion of an on-screen file that has been marked as subject to user action.
The Microsoft web browser.
To combine products for sale as a lot. Frequently, operating system software and some widely used applications are bundled with a computer system for sale.
A file or set of files that defines the data structure, appearance, and behavior of a form.
A filter effect in Windows Movie Maker.
A unique identifier of an object or person.
A unique identifier of an object or person.
A computer that provides shared resources, such as files or printers, to network users.
To configure a device or application so that it performs better. For example, to fine-tune a program so that it runs more quickly or takes up less space.
A software control that incorporates ActiveX technology.
A picture made from a series of small dots, much like a piece of graph paper with certain squares filled in to form shapes and lines.
Pertaining to a type of access to data in a database that is shared over a network. When you open a database in exclusive mode, you prevent others from opening the database.
A supplemental program that can extend the capabilities of an application program.
To tap twice quickly on a screen or touchpad.
To adjust the perspective of an image or document in order to view a larger area on the screen at one time, as if viewed from farther away.
The menu choice that allows a user to customize application behavior.
A customizable toolbar that provides one-click access to commands.

A card, plug, or other device that connects pieces of hardware with the computer so that information can be moved from place to place. For example, standardized interfaces such as RS-232-C standard and SCSI enable communications between computers and printers or disks.
A capability of many programs and operating systems to display advice or instructions for using their features when so requested by the user, as by a screen button or menu item or a function key.

In facsimile and other optical technologies, to move a light-sensitive device across an image-bearing surface such as a page of text, converting the light and dark areas on the surface to binary digits that can be interpreted by a computer.
An individual song or other discrete piece of audio content.

A button that represents an item or program that is open and running on your computer. For example, if you open Microsoft Word, and then minimize it, it will be displayed as a taskbar button, which you can then click when you want to maximize it.

To detect, locate, and correct logical or syntactical errors in a program or malfunctions in hardware. In hardware contexts, the term troubleshoot is the term more often used, especially when the problem is a major one.

Of or relating to communications systems in which the medium of transmission (such as a wire or fiber-optic cable) carries multiple messages at a time, each message modulated on its own carrier frequency by a modem.
The Windows technology that collects data when the system crashes or stops responding and sends it to Microsoft.
To mark text, cells, and similar items that will be subject to a user action, such as copying text.
The menu item that allows the play back all of the items in a playlist once, in random order. Playback ends when all of the items in the list have been played one time.
A network of computers, printers, and other devices located within a relatively limited area (for example, a building). A LAN enables any connected device to interact with any other on the network.
A network of computers, printers, and other devices located within a relatively limited area (for example, a building). A LAN enables any connected device to interact with any other on the network.

The process of seeking a particular file or specific data. A search is carried out by a program through comparison or calculation to determine whether a match to some pattern exists or whether some other criteria have been met.

To perform an action that entails pressing a finger or the tip of a pen to the screen, holding it down until a mouse icon or menu appears, and then lifting the finger or pen. Pressing and holding is equivalent to right-clicking with a mouse.
To move the pointer over a UI element for a specified duration with the intent of interacting with that element.
Completed or passed. The measured duration of an event.
A handheld portable telephone that operates through a radio network.
To move an object one pixel at a time.
The basic building block of a macro; a self-contained instruction that can be combined with other actions to automate tasks. This is sometimes called a command in other macro languages.

The person responsible for setting up and managing local computers, stand-alone servers, member servers, or domain controllers. An administrator performs such duties as assigning user accounts and passwords, establishing security access levels, watching for unauthorized access, allocating storage space, and helping users with networking problems.

The person responsible for setting up and managing local computers, stand-alone servers, member servers, or domain controllers. An administrator performs such duties as assigning user accounts and passwords, establishing security access levels, watching for unauthorized access, allocating storage space, and helping users with networking problems.
To prepare a disk, computer, device, or system for use.
The computational and control unit of a computer. The CPU is the device that interprets and executes instructions.
The computational and control unit of a computer. The CPU is the device that interprets and executes instructions.
A commercial organization.
An alphanumeric code assigned to all addresses in order to facilitate mail delivery.
A peripheral device whose purpose is to allow the user to provide input to a computer system. Examples of input devices are keyboards, mice, joysticks, and styluses.
One character (or more) that is slightly higher than other text on a line, such as a footnote reference mark.
An order for a SKU that is currently not available for delivery.
A Windows technology that protects OS resources (files, folders registry keys) and prevents applications and administrators from making changes to a computer's resources in an arbitrary way.
A memory measurement unit that is equal to 1 million bytes.
A memory measurement unit that is equal to 1 million bytes.
In computing, a characteristic of data that is represented as binary digits (zeros and ones).
To make a transmission appear to come from a user other than the user who performed the action.
To adjust horizontal spacing so that text is aligned evenly along both the left and right margins. Justifying text creates a smooth edge on both sides.
A change made to content, such as a file, document, or post.
To set a variable to an initial value.
Amusment, pleasure, or diversion.
A calendar item that includes reserved resources and/or invited attendees.
A legal agreement between a software or hardware manufacturer and the end user, with regard to the terms of use and transfer of the software.

The extension of a private network that encompasses encapsulated, encrypted, and authenticated links across shared or public networks. VPN connections typically provide remote access and router-to-router connections to private networks over the Internet.

The extension of a private network that encompasses encapsulated, encrypted, and authenticated links across shared or public networks. VPN connections typically provide remote access and router-to-router connections to private networks over the Internet.
A link between two or more communications devices.
A device used to connect wireless computers and other wireless devices to a wired network.
To end a user session for an Internet account. For example, you sign out of a Microsoft account, an Internet service provider account, or Skype.
Hearing impairment that results in complete loss of hearing.
A framework that includes rows and columns for organizing and arranging content on a form, including controls, control labels, sections of a form, logos, and other types of graphics.
A general class of software used to detect spyware and sometimes remove it.
A symbol used to represent the Control key on the keyboard. For example, ^Z means "hold the Control key down and press the Z key."
To accept changes to data in a record.
The data type that holds a maximum of 8,000 characters.
An action statement in any computer language, most often in machine or assembly language. Most programs consist of two types of statements: declarations and instructions.
Video images and sound stored in a digital format.
Video images and sound stored in a digital format.
A graphical user interface control that is equipped with a small bar which slides along a visible line and is used to set a value along a range with a minimum and maximum.
To reduce a window to a button on the taskbar by clicking the Minimize button (leftmost button on the right side of the title bar) or by pressing ALT+SPACEBAR and then pressing N.
A single location in Windows where you can adjust mobile PC settings.
A file that contains encoded information that is interpreted according to the application that created it. In general, a binary file can be edited only by the application in which it was created.
An interactive technology in Microsoft Excel or Access that can show dynamic views of the same data from a list or a database.
Confidence in the reliability of an entity or service and the information that it provides.
A user interface control that facilitates modification of an object's appearance, position, or behavior.
The date by which some task or action should be completed.

A graphic element that appears similar to a physical button or keyboard key in the UI. A button is "pressed" by clicking on it with a mouse, by hitting ENTER or RETURN on the keyboard (if the button has the focus) or tapping by a finger.
An automated tool that helps find and fix specific problems on your computer.
The key on the keyboard that is labeled with a left arrow.
The Microsoft technology that facilitates the installation of updates to Windows operating systems by scanning and installing to client systems in a way that permits end user control over the process
The app that calculates (standard and scientific) and converts.
The app that calculates (standard and scientific) and converts.
The window in which a user is currently working or directing input. An active window is typically at the top of the Z order and is distinguished by the color of its title bar.
A field data type that can contain up to 255 characters or the number of characters specified by the Fieldsize property, whichever is less.
A unit of measure referring to the height of a printed character. A point equals 1/72 of an inch, or approximately 1/28 of a centimeter.

The part of the Microsoft Office user interface above the main work area that presents commands and options to the user. The Ribbon replaced menus and toolbars starting in the 2007 Microsoft Office system.
A field data type that can contain up to 65,535 characters.
An orientation where the long dimension of a rectangular area (for example, screen, photo, or paper) is horizontal.
A number assigned to a specific inventory item to identify it and differentiate it from similar items with the same item number.
A logical network connection between two entities such as a user or computer, that has a defined lifetime and associated state, and that might involve multiple physical connections.
To pick a command or an option from within a graphical user interface, as by clicking a button in a dialog box or pulling down a menu and then releasing the mouse button on one of its options.

A page that contains the design and layout elements that you want to repeat on multiple pages in a publication. Using master pages for these common elements gives your publication a more consistent appearance.
A box with dotted borders in a slide layout that holds title and body text or objects such as charts, tables, and pictures.
To continue to press a keyboard key or mouse button.
A protocol that makes it possible for users to sync their email, calendar, contact, and task data from Exchange Server to supporting devices.
A lightweight and task-specific add-in program that integrates with applications to expose data at a glance.
The amount of storage space available for storing and processing on a disc.

A markup language for describing and exchanging structured data in a format that is independent of operating systems and applications. XML is a World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) specification and is a subset of Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML).
In a cascading style sheet style definition (or style rule), the HTML element linked to a particular set of style properties and values.

An address that uniquely identifies a location on the Internet. A URL is usually preceded by http://, as in http://www.microsoft.com. A URL can contain more detail, such as the name of a page of hypertext, often with the file name extension .html or .htm.
An agreement in which a customer prepays for periodic or regular services.
The , character.
A predefined or free-form figure — such as a line, oval, cube, flowchart symbol, banner, or free-form scribble — that the user can insert into a document and then customize.
In computer graphics, a display method in which a viewing window on the screen scans horizontally or vertically, like a camera, to bring offscreen extensions of the current image smoothly into view.

A common point of entry for spyware guarded by an agent. Examples of checkpoints include Startup Folder, dial up connections, Wi-Fi connections, Internet Safe Sites, Winsock Layered Service Providers, Windows Messenger Service, and SPAM Zombie prevention.
To enlarge a window to its largest size by double-clicking the title bar, clicking the Maximize button (at the right of the title bar), or by pressing ALT+SPACEBAR and then pressing X.
Pertaining to an operator that can hold an arbitrary number of arguments, or to a function that can hold an arbitrary number of operators.
Pertaining to an operator that can hold an arbitrary number of arguments, or to a function that can hold an arbitrary number of operators.
Capable of being retrieved (read), printed or copied but not changed (written) or saved.
An apartment that consists of one or more threads.
An apartment that consists of one or more threads.
On a local area network (LAN), a drive that other computers on the network can connect to. A network drive allows people to access shared files and folders.
Having a frequency in the electromagnetic spectrum in the range just below that of red light.
To create an object, such as an email message.
A client software component that declares a client's health state (by providing a statement of health) to a NAP agent.

The condition at a particular time of any of numerous elements of computing--a device, a communications channel, a network station, a program, a bit, or other element--used to report on or to control computer operations.

The condition at a particular time of any of numerous elements of computing--a device, a communications channel, a network station, a program, a bit, or other element--used to report on or to control computer operations.
An integrated proofing tool used to search on common words and display synonyms.
The time for which a dry or alkaline cell is able to produce an electric current before it needs to be replaced.

Characterized by conversational exchange of input and output, as when a user enters a question or command and the system immediately responds. The interactivity of microcomputers is one of the features that makes them approachable and easy to use.
An exponentiation operator used in some programming languages. For example, the expression 3^2 represents the number 3 raised to the second power.

A link between a user's computer and a group of computers and other devices that enables the user to access printers, servers etc. The link can be through a wire, cable, phone line or wireless transmissions.
Pertaining to a product that can work with or is equivalent to another product.
The data transfer capacity (speed of transmission) of a digital communications system as measured in bits per second (bps).
A key that accompanies a graphic and explains how information is presented.
A feature that enables users to provide input through the screen by using a finger or a pen.
To reverse playback of a digital media file at a speed that is faster than normal.
A function that takes a key, label, and seed as input, then produces an output of arbitrary length.

A character used to separate directory names in MS-DOS and UNIX path specifications. When used as a leading character, it means that the path specification begins from the topmost level for that disk drive.
To turn a device off and back on again, either manually, or by clicking Restart.
A single position or item in a dimension. Dimension members can be user-defined or predefined and can have properties associated with them.
A Web-oriented technology developed by Microsoft that is designed to enable server-side scripting.
The control panel for Office (including the Tools Options dialog).
To copy files from a backup storage device to their normal location, especially if the files are being copied to replace files that were accidentally lost or deleted.

The visual experience of the premium Windows Vista editions. Windows Aero builds on the Basic and Standard user experiences to offer customers our best-designed, highest-performing desktop environment. A noticeable element of the new Windows Aero experience is the professional-looking, transparent glass design, which creates an open, lightweight environment but more importantly enables users to focus on their content rather than the interface.
A specified amount of processing performed as a unit by a computer.
The primary circuit board in a computer that contains most of the basic components of the system.
To initiate another response.
A set of data that is organized and summarized into a multidimensional structure that is defined by a set of dimensions and measures.

An upgrade option that allows users to upgrade from one edition of Windows to another by purchasing the upgrade online. It is enabled by Software Licensing Services (SLS) technology which allows a digital lincense to determine what features are enabled or disabled allowing Microsoft to sell either additional licenses or product upgrades through digital licenses (PUP-DL). Customers may either buy full packaged product (FPP) or upgrade quickly and conveniently electronically.
In database management, an identifier for a record or group of records in a datafile.
A number used to indicate the cost of a route in the Internet Protocol (IP) routing table that enables the selection of the best route among possible multiple routes to the same destination.

An unsolicited and typically unwelcome message, often commercial or political in nature, transmitted via the Internet as a mass mailing (sometimes as if from a fictitious user or domain) to a large number of recipients.
To perform an instruction.
Pertaining to something that functions without external control.
The process of quitting all programs before closing the operating system.
A server that hosts and delivers media across a network.
A computer monitor that supplements the main monitor.
The output created in desktop publishing applications.
A set of instructions for retrieving specific data from a large set, usually with multiple conditions. No list is displayed until you run the query.

A downloadable Web application that helps Windows users identify which edition of Windows meets their needs, whether their PCs are ready for an upgrade to the next Windows version, and which features of the suggested Windows version will be able to run on their PCs.
Data and the information needed to access that data from programs and databases that support the Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) protocol.
A long key occupying much of the bottom row of most keyboards that sends a space character to the computer.
A long key occupying much of the bottom row of most keyboards that sends a space character to the computer.
The Internet protocol used to deliver information over the World Wide Web.
The Internet protocol used to deliver information over the World Wide Web.

In programming, a list of data values, all of the same type, any element of which can be referenced by an expression consisting of the array name followed by an indexing expression. Arrays are part of the fundamentals of data structures, which, in turn, are a major fundamental of computer programming.
To place information from storage into memory for processing, if it is data, or for execution, if it is program code.
The "digital persona" by which other users recognize and interact with you.
An instruction to a computer program that, when issued by the user, causes an action to be carried out.
The client software that enables users to connect to a remote computer that has the Remote Desktop feature enabled or to a remote desktop server.
A fixed-length data type with a maximum length of 8,000 bytes of binary data.
A special version of Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) that includes diagnostic, troubleshooting, and maintenance tools.
In some applications (especially databases), a structured window, box, or other self-contained element that serves as a visual filter for the underlying data it is presenting.
