One mouse click (usually with the left mouse button).
A type of drop-down menu that appears when a user points to a command on a higher-level menu.
A user-friendly name displayed in place of a network location, email address, contact name, or other, more formal names.
A list of programs or tasks waiting for execution.
The ` character.
The ` character.
The field on a form in which the cursor or pointer is positioned.
To assign a drive letter, port, or computer name to a shared resource so that you can use it.
Possessing improved, advanced, or more sophisticated features.

A window that shows the design of these database objects - tables, queries, forms, reports, macros, and data access pages. In Design view, you can create new database objects and modify the design of existing ones.
An area of an application window that enables the user to navigate quickly to different parts of the program.
The process of inputting information.

A list of items that a customer has selected to purchase from a commerce Web site. It is usually compiled into a file and sometimes visually represented by a shopping basket, shopping cart, or other container used when shopping.
An item in the Windows Control Panel that enables users to access Parental Controls and other third-party parental control features, such as web filters.
The ‐ character, used to break a word between syllables at the end of a line or to separate the parts of a compound word.
An item on the Control Panel that provides user a comprehensive view over all roamed content, as well as ability to check on the synchronization progress of individual items.
A property of an object that can be quantified numerically.
A device that puts text or images on paper or other print media.
The hardware-based security feature that prevents unauthorized access to a computer by providing full-volume encryption and integrity checking of boot components.
The hardware-based security feature that prevents unauthorized access to a computer by providing full-volume encryption and integrity checking of boot components.
An application that contains a linked or embedded OLE object from another application.

A file system defined by the Optical Storage Technology Association (OSTA) that is the successor to the CD-ROM file system (CDFS). UDF is used for removable disk media like DVD, CD, and magneto-optic (MO) disks.
A hardware device, or a logical partition of it, that reads data from and writes data to hard disks.
A visual impairment that results in complete loss of vision in both eyes.

A uniquely-named collection of computers in a networked environment that share a common database, directory database, or tree and that is administered as a unit with common rules and procedures, which can include security policies.

A group of preset power-management options. For example, you can set elapsed times for putting your computer on standby and for turning off your monitor and hard disk. You save these settings as a named power scheme.

A group of preset power-management options. For example, you can set elapsed times for putting your computer on standby and for turning off your monitor and hard disk. You save these settings as a named power scheme.
To position objects or text relative to some point, such as the page margin.
Pertaining to a file format that allows for VBA code. Examples of file extensions for macro-enabled formats are .docm, .pptm, .xlsm.
In Windows Media Player, a database that contains information about digital media files on a computer, a network drive, or the Internet.
One or more rows of cells commonly used to display numbers and other items for quick reference and analysis.
One character (or more) printed slightly below the baseline of surrounding text.
In the context of processes or tasks that are part of an operating system or program, operating without interaction with the user while the user is working on another task.
To advance audio or video playback at a speed that is faster than normal.

A type of attack that tries to trick users into revealing personal information, such as credit card numbers, bank accounts, or passwords, often using links to fake websites included in emails and chat messages.
An item provided and signed by the DCE security server that is both a proof of identity and a list of group memberships.
An apartment that consists of exactly one thread.
An apartment that consists of exactly one thread.
To ensure that all data sources that are used by a KPI or scorecard are available.
A service or feature that renders the audio content of a television or video program as text on the screen. These captions are usually visible only if decoded or activated.
A numeric or other designation appended to a product name to identify a particular release.​
An effect applied to a graphical object that typically reduces the difference between the outline of the object and the graphical area next to it.
Software that provides encryption for sensitive data, such as passwords, in applications.
A Microsoft site that provides a comprehensive listing of updates that can be distributed over a corporate network.

A feature of Remote Desktop Services that enables the user to access a program remotely through Remote Desktop Services but have it appear as if it is running on the user's local computer. Users can run RemoteApp programs side by side with their local programs.
The date when a project or task is scheduled to begin.
To eliminate an entity by removing it from a list, database, or other item, or by uninstalling it.
To set an entity, such as a feature, configuration, or object, back to its defaults.
To locate text or a specific item on a Web page or in a document.
The navigation button used to complete and close a wizard.
A user who does not have a user account or who does not provide a password.
A group of reusable settings that describes the shared attributes and behaviors of a list item, a document, or a folder.
A feature that tracks and stores a record of a shared document when it is first created, and each time it is edited.
The expected total cost of a task or project, based on performance as of the status date. EAC is calculated as follows: EAC = ACWP + (BAC-BCWP)/CPI.
A format used by the Bentley MicroStation CAD program to store drawing files.
The original project, resource, and assignment cost as shown in the baseline plan. The baseline cost is a snapshot of the cost at the time when the baseline plan was saved.
To briefly press a UI element with your fingertip or stylus to perform an activity (such as choosing an action from a menu or opening an item). A "tap" is normally around 0.1 second in duration.

The difference between the budgeted cost of work performed [BCWP] and the budgeted cost of work scheduled [BCWS]. This is calculated as follows: SV = Budgeted Cost of Work Performed - Budgeted Cost of Work Scheduled.
A Project view that displays a project's tasks in a calendar format.

The code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.

The code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.

The code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.
The shape of how scheduled work for an assignment is distributed across time. Use a contour to control how Project schedules the work of a resource.
In the Charts And Graphs template, a control handle on the Line Graph shape that you can drag to change the values in the graph.
The amount of time between the scheduled start of a task and the time when work should actually begin on the task.
A text string that unambiguously refers to a hardware or software component under a certain context and can be used to access the data in that component.
Data that is stored outside of the application that is currently in use.
A rank or category assigned to a material resource that denotes functional use but not level of quality. A low-grade resource is not necessarily a low-quality resource.
Resolving resource conflicts or overallocations by delaying or splitting certain tasks. When Project levels a resource, its selected assignments are distributed and rescheduled.
A shape on a stencil that you use repeatedly to create drawings. When you drag a shape from a stencil onto the drawing page, the shape becomes an instance of that master.

Principles that guide developers as they assign responsibilities to software classes and design system behavior. They are most useful when creating collaboration diagrams where messages imply responsibility.
A schedule of task start and finish dates and resource and cost data.
Placing elements, such as text and graphics, on a page to let the page author control the exact location and layer order of a page element.
The degree of excellence, or the desired standards, in a product, process, or project.
To move a task to a lower outline level [to the right] in the Task Name field. When you indent a task, it becomes a subtask of the nearest preceding task at a higher outline level.
A representation of the communication path between actors.
An actor's interface component through which actors communicate with other actors.
Any one-dimensional (1-D) shape that can be glued between two shapes in a drawing to connect the shapes.
To change the dimensions of a shape by dragging one of its handles after it has been selected with the pointer tool.
A small overlap that extends the shape of the upper of two differently colored, abutting objects. A spread extends beyond the area that it knocks out.
A date that you set [rather than the current date] for reporting the time, cost, or performance condition of a project.
An horizontal or vertical line that divides a diagram into partitions and which is used to arrange related parts of a process.
Any application or process that you want to model. Examples of systems include a computer game, a process for assembling microchips, and a library information system.
The percentage of a work resource’s time that is assigned to a task.
An XML structure that consists of a start tag, an end tag, and the information between the tags. Elements can have attributes and can contain other elements.
Pertaining to information that shows what has actually occurred. For example, the actual start date for a task is the day that the task actually started.
The percentage of a resource's capacity that is designated for a specific assignment.
An allowed path from one state to another.
The number of levels that a task is indented from the top level of the outline. You can indent tasks up to 65,000 levels in Project.
A group of related tasks that completes a major step in a project.
Conditions you specify to limit which records are included in the result set of a query or filter.
A diagram that shows dependencies between project tasks. Tasks are represented by boxes, or nodes, and task dependencies are represented by lines that connect the boxes.

A feature that enables users to build robust, targeted queries that include search operators. The least complex of which are the Boolean operators many users are familiar with. In addition, customers can use advanced operators such as "contains:" or "inanchor:" or "site:" Customers can add operator upon operator and watch their query change in the search box.
A notification that is displayed to a user when user-defined criteria are met.
To package your publication files by using the Pack and Go Wizard.
The ability of one element to see or refer to another. For one element to send a message to another element, the latter must be visible to the former.
To display an object.
A file that stores an image as graphical objects (lines, circles, polygons) rather than as pixels. Metafiles preserve an image more accurately than pixels when the image is resized.
A page that you can assign to another page to create multiple layers in a drawing.
The size of the sheet of paper on which you print the publication, before trimming.

The audio effect ​that creates the perception that there are many more sources of sound then are currently present. This is a well-known and industry term for the technique of creating a surround sound experience for users listening to audio with regular stereo headphones.
A file that contains the data that a program will process and store in a destination file.
To accept an incoming telephone call.
To execute a program.
A picture made by combining a series of photos into one large picture to provide a complete view of an area or location that cannot fit in a single shot.

Meeting an organization's various obligations, which may arise from laws, regulations, rules, and many other legal instruments, such as court judgments, litigation, and even contracts. Specific and important examples of these obligations include the Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX) and the California Law on Notice of Security Breach, formerly known as SB-1386. These regulatory obligations may be created by many sources, such as national and local governments and from industry-specific oversight groups, such as the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standards.
A collection of communications (email, IM, text messaging, voice mail, and so on) between two or more participants.

A collection of shapes arranged in a tree structure that helps analyze and summarize data in a visual, easy-to-understand format. It starts out as a single shape, called a top node, that contains information imported from a worksheet, table, view, or cube.
A policy that specifies the length of time during which items such as data, documents, builds, and releases are to be retained.
A communication technology based on short range (4cm or less) wireless data exchange.
When referring to the use of licensed products, the misuse or any departure from the reasonable use of such products.
The information provided with a product by a manufacturer describing how to use a product.

A collection of visual elements and sounds for your computer desktop or device User Interface. A theme determines the look of the various visual elements of your User Interface, such as windows, icons, fonts, and colors, and it can include sounds.

The Internet Explorer feature that allows users to surf the Web without leaving a browsing history, cookies or other information on the PC so they can do online banking on a shared computer, for example.

A virtual community that provides people with opportunities to interact (via blogs, chats, newsgroups, webcasts, user groups, and forums) with Microsoft employees, experts, and peers in order to share knowledge and news about Microsoft technology.
An alert that is set by the user to be activated at a particular time.
A renamed .cab file which contains a .theme file, and optionally one or more desktop backgrounds, icons, mouse pointer files, and sound files. It does not contain executables or screen savers.
A folder that stores the user's graphics, e.g. digital pictures. Many graphic design and photo-editing programs use this location by default to open or save graphic files.

An option on the Views menu in File Explorer that shows the most appropriate details for the file type in a flexible layout rather than only showing the details associated with the column headers in the view.
The feature in Control Panel that provides the user with a single point of entry for tasks and notifications related to security and general PC software maintenance.
A group of computers on a home network that can share pictures, music, videos, documents, and printers. A homegroup is created by using the HomeGroup feature; it is protected with a password.
A password that helps prevent unauthorized access to homegroup files and printers.
An action that removes redundant messages from an email conversation to reduce information overload and improve readability.
A collection of items, such as files and folders, assembled from various locations. The locations might be on your computer, an external hard drive, removable media, or someone else’s computer.
To mark an item so that it always appears in a specific place in the UI or in a list.
To remove an item, such as a tile, library, movie, game, or app, from a given area of the UI, to make it inaccessible in that area.
A user with role-based permission who can change settings for apps, services, users, subscriptions, and/or devices.
A pencil tool that works with texture and simulates a real life pencil in stroke.
A Windows feature that enables users to easily roll back their PC to an earlier good state while keeping their data safe.
A frame that contains text, shapes, pictures, or other content. A slide is a digital equivalent to a traditional film slide.
A Windows tool used to capture a screen shot, or snip, of any object on the screen, and then annotate, save, or share the image.
To mark an email conversation so that all current and future messages in the conversation are automatically moved to the Deleted Items folder.
A feature that allows the user to apply custom or default markers to items (e.g. Outlook messages or OneNote content) in order to categorize information for easy retrieval and sorting.
A feature that allows the user to apply custom or default markers to items (e.g. Outlook messages or OneNote content) in order to categorize information for easy retrieval and sorting.

Any hardware or software that can detect events or environmental changes, such as your current location or the amount of light around your computer. For example, a notebook with a location sensor, such as a Global Positioning System (GPS) receiver, can determine your exact location. An ambient light sensor can detect when there is a change in lighting, and then a program can use that information to adjust the brightness of your screen.

A device that includes an antenna, a radio receiver, and a processor for use with the worldwide GPS (Global Positioning System). A GPS receiver uses position and time information from four GPS satellites to calculate precise information about its current location, its speed of travel, and the current time.
A category of sensor that can detect the current location of your computer.
An area within the Windows Control Panel that provides support for sensors such as enabling, disabling or uninstalling sensors and sensor-enabled applications, changing sensor settings, etc.
An arrangement of search results ordered by relevance using a special search algorithm.
A single set of sign-in credentials (typically, email address and password) that is used to access the services provided by an online service provider (OSP).
The process of maintaining connectivity outside of one's usual service or coverage area.

A handler that displays a lightweight, read-only preview of a file’s contents without launching the application associated with the file. For example, a preview handler displays a Shell item in the Windows Explorer preview pane.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show nonsequential information.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show steps in a process or timeline.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show a continual process.
A menu item that enables users to initiate operations, such as sending an instant message or playing a game.
A recognition feature that helps increase input speed and reduce effort by providing users with word completion and next word prediction alternates as the user is writing/typing.
An extension of the conventional touch input feature to allow multiple fingers touching the computer or device screen at the same time.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving in opposite directions (-> <- or <- ->).
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving around a center point or one finger moving around a finger that is not moving.
The worldwide collection of networks and gateways that use the TCP/IP suite of protocols to communicate with one another.
A collection of computing resources such as programs and virtual desktops that enable a user to accomplish a set of related tasks.

The entity that offers a remote workspace, typically the IT department of the user’s employer, a business partner or vendor, or less commonly, a commercial application service provider. The publisher may use a digital certificate to represent its identity and use it to sign the remote resource files (e.g. RDP files) and the workspace description (e.g. Web Service feed).
To shut down a core processor for power saving purpose.
A unique identifier made from four otherwise separate pieces of information. For example, a color can be specified by a black, yellow, magenta and cyan quad.
To make an object, such as a file, accessible.
The portion of InfoPath used to design forms.
To remove a user's changes from the Microsoft Office Document Cache without deleting the file on the server or removing the latest version downloaded from the server from the Office Document Cache.
The mode of Windows Photo Viewer which consists of a top level window displaying one photograph at a time, with navigation controls.
A recordable media (such as CD-RW) to which you can only write once without reformatting.
A recordable media to which you can write several times without reformatting.
A set of credentials that users can create, store and manage in Credential Manager.

The Microsoft app that creates sticky notes that can be shared between devices, that cloud sync, that are stored on Exchange, and that provide contextual reminders and actions that can be performed based on the content.
An individual piece of content that resembles a physical sticky note, is displayed across multiple apps and platforms, and that is created using Sticky Notes.
A labeled group of consecutive slides that helps the user navigate and organize presentations.
To establish a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.
To make a single file out of a set of files using a program such as compress, gzip, or PKZIP.

To copy driver binaries, install services, and add registry keys for one or more drivers from a driver package onto a system, without the context of a specific device. A system can be booted from reflected drivers, however full device installation may still be required in order to enable full driver functionality.
A Windows library that allows users to store, manage and share all their recorded TV items.
A Windows feature that provides a direct connection to a corporate network for people working outside of the office. It is a superior alternative to VPN.
A PC (desktop and beyond) search platform that allows search of the local hard drive plus network locations like SharePoint sites and the Internet.
A set of attributes that define a user's access to a given service or application.
To break a connection.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to compare or show the relationship between two ideas. Each of the first two lines of Level 1 text corresponds to text at the top of one side of the center point. Emphasizes Level 2 text, which is limited to four shapes on each side of the center point. The balance tips towards the side with the most shapes containing Level 2 text. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
Marked by the use of serifs. For example, Goudy is a serif typeface, whereas Helvetica is a sans serif typeface.
A company that provides services or content for its customers.
A type of personal identification number (PIN) for the SIM card, consisting of 4 digits, that is used to gain access to your mobile phone.
To expose a virtual disk to the user, backed by a file.

The administrative task of making remote resources available to its users, setting policies that control how users will connect, how they will find the remote resources, and what settings users will connect with.
To uninstall all software on a computer and reinstall a new Windows image.
A small pop-up window that informs users of a non-critical problem or special condition in a control.
A sensor that uses ultrasound, infrared, heat or vibration stimuli to detect movement.
A biometric sensor that analyses your eye retina to recognize or authenticate identity.
A category of sensor that can respond to an applied stimulus by generating an electrical signal.
A category of sensor that is used for mechanical measurement of force, scale, pressure, strain, etc.
A category of sensor that tracks environmental changes such as temperature, atmospheric pressure, humidity, wind speed and wind direction.
A type of sensor that can determine without physical contact if an object/person is nearby, or can be used to measure the distance between the object/person and the sensor device.

A type of sensor (such as a proximity sensor) that uses radio frequency identification (RFID) for a numerous purposes, such as identification of physical items, automatic log on, location of people, etc.
A sensor that responds to a pre-defined amount of light.
A view mode in Internet Explorer that determines whether content is rendered as if users were viewing it in a previous version of Internet Explorer.
An Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) 802.11 wireless network in which Service Set Identifier (SSID) suppression is enabled.

The feature that prevents Internet Explorer from storing data about your browsing session. This helps prevent anyone else who might be using your computer from seeing where you visited and what you looked at on the Web.
The feature that blocks third-party web content that could potentially track someone's web activity.
A computer that belongs to a homegroup.
A troubleshooter that helps find and fix problems with viewing computers or shared files in a homegroup.
To group together multiple windows of the same application under a single button on the taskbar’s taskband.
A software or device that helps control your home smart devices automatically.

An input device used chiefly for identification purposes that reads information that has been magnetically encoded, usually in two tracks, on a plastic card, such as a credit card or an employee badge.
A notebook that is smaller in size and lighter in weight than a full-sized notebook, while retaining the same functionality.
A node that makes cached data available to clients needing to retrieve the data.
To apply a marker to content or items (like photos or text) to identify certain types of information.

A COM-based multimedia platform and infrastructure for digital media in Microsoft Windows. It focuses on content protection, audio and video quality, and interoperability for digital rights management (DRM).

A COM-based multimedia platform and infrastructure for digital media in Microsoft Windows. It focuses on content protection, audio and video quality, and interoperability for digital rights management (DRM).

A search location exposed via .osdx templates and made possible via the OpenSearch technology. It connects the local search indexer to a remote index and provides the end user with the ability to search for files on a Web site or on an intranet site from within Windows.
A Web site from Microsoft which provides solutions for the top issues about Windows Update or Microsoft Update, and enables you to contact a support professional.
A view that shows all of the resources on a project and their work over time. This makes it easy to rearrange work, schedule new work, and manage a team's load.
To permit someone else to perform an action.
The navigation button used to return to recently visited Web pages in Internet Explorer, Microsoft Edge, and other internet browsers.
A term that can be added to a search to filter the results by a specific property (for example, by author). Relevant search filters appear under the search box in any open folder.

A soft keyboard that is displayed with a different set of settings by default (larger buttons, bigger size, etc.) when you launch the Tablet PC Input Panel with touch. This is to facilitate touch input.
A small, affordable laptop that is designed to perform a limited number of tasks such as web browsing and email.
A real-time, physical action applied to an object, in which multiple contact points are used simultaneously.

A slide show mode that displays content in a manageable window that can be resized and features navigation buttons. This mode is optimized for reviewing presentations, allowing users to get the full experience, complete with animations and media, while performing other tasks, such as taking notes.
A high-level linear representation of a project schedule that can be easily formatted, annotated, and copied and pasted from Project into other Office applications.
The combination of hardware (touchscreen or touchpad) and software elements that provides a way to control programs by touching multiple points on the screen simultaneously.
The street address or geographical coordinates of a user, and (by way of extensions) of the user’s computer or devices.
The feature that allows users to stream music, images or videos to a specific device on their home network.
To enter information by means of the keyboard or other input method.
A site element that stores and displays a collection of data that team members and other site users can share.
A standard control that resembles a notebook and lets the user navigate different sections of information without leaving the current element on the screen.
An ability to view data or navigate to or within a physical or virtual computer environment.
To combine thereby increasing the quantity or size of something.
A UI or media segment that can display on top of or play concurrently with another UI or media segment.
A powerful stand-alone computer of the sort used in computer-aided design and other applications requiring a high-end, usually expensive, machine with considerable calculating or graphics capability.
On retailer websites, a collection of desired products or items a customer saves to their user account for future reference.
To return to a stable condition after some error has occurred. A program recovers from an error by stabilizing itself and resuming execution of instructions without user intervention.
A process that restricts the flow of data.
The file name extension of a data file that stores your messages and other items on your computer.
A task page in the Windows Control Panel from where customers can get real-time status information about their network, and also make changes to settings.
The set of Microsoft software for email, instant messaging, photos, and personal movies available to customers in a single download and installation.
A geographical area that observes the same local time.
An option that isolates the foreground portion of an image and make the background transparent.
To set again with a different value.

A feature that uses speech recognition to enable you to interact with your computer or other devices by voice. You can dictate documents and emails in mainstream applications, and use voice commands to start and switch between applications, control the operating system and even fill out forms on the web.
A text-based post on Twitter.
The Bing service that allows search and view of maps and satellite images.
An annotation that describes or emphasizes an element of a drawing or image and is typically connected to that drawing or image by a line.
Descriptive text that represents the audio content of a television or video program as text on the screen.
Descriptive text that represents the audio content of a television or video program as text on the screen.
A tab on the ribbon that takes users to Microsoft Office Backstage view.
A feature of Microsoft Office that allows the user to view and edit image document formats like .TIF, which is the format most traditionally used in fax transmissions (IOs, T&Cs, etc.).
An online process that confirms whether installed software was properly activated.
The year 2010 edition of the Microsoft messaging and collaboration client software for personal computers accessing Microsoft Exchange Server-based email and collaboration services.
An online community where members can virtually socialize by posting and commenting on a newsfeed, by chatting, and by sharing photos, images, articles, and other content.
A prewritten formula that simplifies the process of entering calculations and enables the user to use formulas that might be difficult to build from scratch.
A view for delivering a presentation that displays it as the audience will see it.
To add a personal touch to something.
An application that is meant to run on a desktop or laptop computer.
An online action, such as updating a status message, publishing photos, or updating profile info.
To connect to a resource, either remotely or locally.
The feature that allows users to navigate directly to the webpage of the top-ranked search result when a search is performed in the address bar.
The public multinational corporation that develops, manufactures, licenses, and supports a wide range of products and services predominantly related to computing.
The public multinational corporation that develops, manufactures, licenses, and supports a wide range of products and services predominantly related to computing.
A visual representation such as a picture, chart or table.
A process of repeated installation of a product, feature, tool, kit, pack, etc.
An operating-system installation and configuration that uses a virtual hard disk as the running operating system. There is no host operating system or hypervisor in a native-boot configuration.
A tablet-style portable computer that's designed for touch input and that lacks an integrated physical keyboard.
A demonstration of a product or service that a customer interacts with to see how features work.
A demonstration of a product or service that a customer interacts with to see how features work.
A setting that allows a user to turn off cellular, Wi-Fi, and Bluetooth on the phone simultaneously. Often required during takeoff and landing in an aircraft.
The actual software bits available to developers to enable them to use the Live Connect program.
A Microsoft sub-brand grouping digital-media products, including devices that play media, a software media player, and online media services.
The feature of account.microsoft.com that lets you ring, lock, erase, or show a user’s phone on a map from any Internet-connected device.
A tile that updates dynamically to show content directly from the Start screen.
Logo assigned to the products that have passed Microsoft-designed tests for compatibility and reliability on Windows 7.
Logo assigned to the software products that have passed Microsoft designed tests for compatibility and reliability on Windows 7.
Logo assigned to the hardware products that have passed Microsoft designed tests for compatibility and reliability on Windows 7.
A program designed to identify compatible and reliable systems, software, and hardware products that have passed Microsoft-designed tests for compatibility and reliability on Windows 7.
A program used to detect spyware and sometimes remove it.
A program that shows details about a computer's hardware configuration, computer components, and software, including drivers.
A program that shows details about a computer's hardware configuration, computer components, and software, including drivers.

The infrastructure that manages low-level graphics-related tasks, such as output adapter and swap chain configuration, and provides a common framework for managing virtualized graphics components and resources.

The infrastructure that manages low-level graphics-related tasks, such as output adapter and swap chain configuration, and provides a common framework for managing virtualized graphics components and resources.
A continuous sequence of characters that share a common format.

A certificate extension that contains information useful for verifying the trust status of a certificate, as defined by the 2008 Memo of the Network Working Group. This information potentially includes Uniform Resource Locations (URLs) where the issuing CA’s certificate can be retrieved, as well as a location of an Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) responder configured to provide status for the certificate in question.

A certificate extension that contains information useful for verifying the trust status of a certificate, as defined by the 2008 Memo of the Network Working Group. This information potentially includes Uniform Resource Locations (URLs) where the issuing CA’s certificate can be retrieved, as well as a location of an Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) responder configured to provide status for the certificate in question.
The basic software module for by smart cards that performs cryptography and includes algorithms for authentication, encoding, and encryption.

ᎠᏌᎹᏗ ᏆᎾᏲᏍᏗ ᎬᏍᎦᎴᏍᏗ ᎪᏪᎸ ᎢᏯᏓᏛᏁᏗ ᎠᏁᏢᏍᎩ

descripGrp.descrip: The basic software module for by smart cards that performs cryptography and includes algorithms for authentication, encoding, and encryption.
The API that supports PKI and X.509 certificates, such as certificate chain validation, certificate stores, and signature verification.
The API that supports PKI and X.509 certificates, such as certificate chain validation, certificate stores, and signature verification.
A certificate extension that indicates where the certificate revocation list for a CA can be retrieved. It can contain none, one, or many HTTP, file, or LDAP URLs.
A certificate extension that indicates where the certificate revocation list for a CA can be retrieved. It can contain none, one, or many HTTP, file, or LDAP URLs.
In a public key infrastructure hierarchy, the certification authority that that issues certificates to users and computers.
In a public key infrastructure hierarchy, the certification authority that that issues certificates to users and computers.
A configuration mode for the Certificate Enrollment Web Service in which it will only process renewal requests.
A hexadecimal string that contains the SHA-1 hash of the certificate.

In Server Manager and Event Viewer, the urgency of an event or error condition, system fault, failure, or action by either the system or the user. Severity can be any of four industry-standard values: Information, Warning, Error, or Critical. These values are defined in the Event Viewer Help.
A process that builds one or more certificate paths. The certificate paths may or may not trace up to a self-signed or root certificate.

A certificate extension used by the certificate chaining engine to determine what certificate was used to sign a presented certificate. The AKI can contain the issuer name, serial number, public key information, or no information at all. By matching the information in a certificate’s AKI extension to a CA certificate’s Subject Key Identifier (SKI) extension, a certificate chain can be built.

A certificate extension used by the certificate chaining engine to determine what certificate was used to sign a presented certificate. The AKI can contain the issuer name, serial number, public key information, or no information at all. By matching the information in a certificate’s AKI extension to a CA certificate’s Subject Key Identifier (SKI) extension, a certificate chain can be built.
A statement that a device makes to indicate that it can be trusted to access secure resources, such a folder on a file share.
A nonfinal release of Windows that's made available to developers.

A statement indicating that the copyright holder reserves, or holds for their own use, all the rights provided by copyright law, such as distribution, performance, and creation of derivative works; that is, they have not waived any such right.
A brief musical composition.
A plan that bills according to data use, such as megabytes downloaded, messages sent, or webpages viewed.
A networking feature that lets one computer directly place information into the memory of another computer.
A networking feature that lets one computer directly place information into the memory of another computer.
A storage pool that exposes physical disks that are currently available for inclusion in a storage pool on a particular storage subsystem.
The layout and general resiliency of data across multiple disks in a virtual disk or storage space.
The layout and general resiliency of data across multiple disks in a virtual disk or storage space.
Pertaining to the resiliency type for a volume that stripes data across physical disks with no resiliency in a Microsoft Storage Spaces storage pool.
A volume that duplicates data across two or three physical disks in a Microsoft Storage Spaces storage pool.
Pertaining to the resiliency type for a volume that stripes data and parity information across physical disks in a Microsoft Storage Spaces storage pool.
A service that enables administration of storage subsystems through a common management API.
A group of physical disks that can be managed together.
A collection of one or more physical disks from a previously created storage pool.
A method of starting the computer that speeds boot time by ending the user session and hibernating the computer, rather than shutting down all running services.

A small amount of executable code contained in the master boot record that scans the partition table for the active partition, finds the starting sector of the active partition, loads a copy of the boot sector from the active partition into memory, and transfers control to the executable code in the boot sector.
A runtime environment for Windows Store apps that's designed to minimize app impact on the computer by placing runtime restrictions on what apps can do.
A filtering feature that monitors downloaded apps for malware or unknown reputation.
A feature of Windows that includes a set of maintenance tasks that run automatically when the user's PC is idle.
A feature of BitLocker that enables IT pros to encrypt a disk before a user begins to use it.
A BitLocker extension that adds management capabilities to BitLocker.
A feature of BitLocker that allows unlocking of an OS volume using a key received over the network.
The Hyper-V technology that runs on the Windows Client operating system, rather than Windows Server.
The ability for IT pros to define how users access a system based on dynamic qualities, such as a user's location or role.
A Windows feature designed to help users avoid data loss by automatically saving versions of files and copies of deleted files so that users can recover them.
The single set of sign-in credentials (email address and password) that provides user access to Microsoft products and services.
A technology that allows for the installation and use of multiple user-interface languages.
A UI element that enables users to locate and select files.
The activation of systems in an enterprise environment by using an established Active Directory implementation and the same key types.
An indicator, such as a message, that informs users of events that are unrelated to their current activity, such as the number of new messages received while their computer is locked.
A certification program to ensure that devices, systems, and apps are compatible, reliable, and can perform to meet Windows standards.
Tools and documentation to certify apps for Windows.
The test automation framework used to certify devices or systems for Windows.
The test automation framework used to certify devices or systems for Windows.
The test automation framework used to certify devices or systems for Windows.
The ability to easily return a PC to a prior state, either by reinstalling Windows and keeping their files or by resetting the PC to the original factory state.
A customized process that identifies and fixes potential problems during PC startup.
The ability for some devices to act like physical smart cards even if they aren't.
The process of activating Windows.
To place at least two fingers on an object and rotate your fingers in a clockwise or counterclockwise direction.
A gesture represented by placing at least two fingers on an object and rotating your fingers in a clockwise or counterclockwise direction.
A gesture represented by placing at least two fingers on an object and rotating your fingers in a clockwise or counterclockwise direction.
A relational data store that's included in Windows and is used by several Windows Services.
A relational data store that's included in Windows and is used by several Windows Services.
A feature that assembles a composite photo collage from multiple source photos.
A process that verifies and eliminates lengthy chkdsk due to any transient errors that NTFS detects.
The process of reducing the number of slabs allocated in thinly provisioned arrays and thinly provisioned virtual disks by rearranging data from sparsely populated slabs to densely populated slabs.
A feature in Windows that communicates with a Microsoft online service to determine a PC's approximate location based on wireless network or IP address info.
An Internet connection created using a metered data plan.

A tool in the Windows ADK that uses assessments to create jobs that evaluate quality and view the results after a job runs. The Windows AC can also package a job and other necessary files, save the files in a folder that contains an executable file, move the job to another computer, and then run the job on the new computer.

A tool in the Windows ADK that uses assessments to create jobs that evaluate quality and view the results after a job runs. The Windows AC can also package a job and other necessary files, save the files in a folder that contains an executable file, move the job to another computer, and then run the job on the new computer.
A feature that provides time events that can be used to initiate background work in suspended apps.
A feature that provides time events that can be used to initiate background work in suspended apps.
A contiguous piece of memory.
A color that affects the background and system controls throughout the new Windows user interface.
A graphical representation that is associated with a user local account for Windows or a Microsoft account.
A UI element that appears along the top or bottom edge of the screen and may include app commands or navigation.
The area that appears behind the tiles on the Start screen.
The Microsoft app to facilitate the management of events.
The Microsoft app to facilitate the management of events.
An app for making video calls.
An app for making video calls.

A user interface element similar to a button that provides access to key Windows features, such as Start, search, sharing, devices, and settings. Charms differ from buttons in that they have extended functionality, such as flyout menus that provide access to individual or grouped commands.
The input panel where users can input text through handwriting. The system converts the handwriting to text that users can insert into the active text area.
The Microsoft app for sending and receiving email.
The Microsoft app for sending and receiving email.
The wider of the two apps that can appear on the screen simultaneously after a second app is snapped to the screen.
The app that facilitates SMS and instant messaging.
The app that facilitates SMS and instant messaging.
The app that facilitates the reading of PDF and XPS files.
The app that facilitates the reading of PDF and XPS files.
The app that facilitates contact list and social update management.
The app that facilitates contact list and social update management.
The app that enables the users to view, organize, edit and share all of their photos from multiple sources.
The app that enables the users to view, organize, edit and share all of their photos from multiple sources.
To move two (or more) fingers toward each other.
To place a finger on the screen and hold it there for a part of a second or more.
A gesture represented by placing a finger on the screen and holding it there for a part of a second or more
To reset the Windows operating system using a method that restores PC settings to defaults but retains a user's files and personalization touches.
To reset the Windows operating system so that all user customizations are removed.
An app that facilitates online file storage.
An app that facilitates online file storage.
To place a finger on the screen, move the finger in one or more directions, and then take the finger off of the screen.
A gesture represented by placing a finger on the screen, moving the finger in one or more directions, and then taking the finger off the screen.
A gesture represented by placing a finger on the screen, moving the finger in one or more directions, and then taking the finger off the screen.
The narrower of the two apps that can appear on the screen simultaneously after a second app is snapped to the screen.
To quickly slide a finger for a short distance.
A gesture represented by a quick slide of a finger over a short distance.
A gesture represented by a quick slide of a finger over a short distance.
A gesture represented by placing a finger or stylus on the screen and then lifting it up, normally within about 0.1 second.
A gesture represented by placing a finger or stylus on the screen and then lifting it up, normally within about 0.1 second.
A word that's suggested as users type, which they can select to quickly insert.
A split on-screen keyboard that is optimized for thumb typing.
A split on-screen keyboard that is optimized for thumb typing.
A moveable object on the Start screen that opens apps or other customized content, like pinned websites.
A contiguous on-screen keyboard.
A contiguous on-screen keyboard.
The brand name of the video offering from Xbox Live.
The brand name of the video offering from Xbox Live.
A feature of Windows that provides a predefined image of a PC from a USB flash drive instead of installing the image on the PC.
An app that facilitates the playing of music.
The app that facilitates the capture of photos and videos by using the PC.
The app that facilitates the capture of photos and videos by using the PC.
To touch an item with two or more fingers and then spread the fingers apart.

An indication that appears on the lock screen or a tile to inform the user of recent activity or updates, such as number of email messages received, since the PC was locked or the app was last viewed.
The feature that audibly reads the text on the screen aloud and describes some events to users.
The feature of Windows for sending tile updates and notifications to users.
The feature of Windows for sending tile updates and notifications to users.
The name of a product in the store that appears to customers. To the end user, this is the name of the product.

Collected data about an app, such as analytics of download, usage, in-application transaction, customer ratings provided by the Windows Store developer portal. This type of information helps developers clearly understand how their applications are doing in the Windows market.
A Windows Store service that enables end users to update apps one at a time or all at the same time for all apps purchased through the Windows Store.
The stage of an app in the certification process.
A link that takes you to a precise location, such as a slide within a presentation, a section of a document, or a specific page within a site, instead of to the main page of the web site.
An API for AtomPub and syndication.
A feature that a developer provides in an app for consumers to buy from within the app through an in-app purchase transaction.
A transaction performed by a consumer from within the context of an app to buy additional features for that app.

Applications in Windows Store are distributed with user-based licensing model. Windows runtime and application model will only allow applications that are for user-based license as well as signed by Windows Store to be installed/run on Windows 8.

termGrp.term: Microsoft ᎠᏓᎵᏍᎪᎸᏓᏁᎯ ᏕᎪᏪᎸᎢ & ᎢᏯᏛᏁᎵᏓᏍᏗ ᎾᎿ ᎾᎾᏛᏁᎲ

descripGrp.descrip: In Windows 8 all windows portal experiences support and persist Live ID logins streamlining the partner experience when working with multiple services and sites.
A type of notification sent via the Microsoft Push Notification Service to an app running on Windows Phone. The format and meaning of the data is determined by the app.
To purchase an app just before downloading and installing it.
To purchase an app after downloading, installing and trying it out.
An image uploaded by the developer that Microsoft can use as a part of promotion via Featured lists and/or marketing campaigns.
The money a developer receives from app and add-on sales in the Windows Store, including advertising revenue.
To move an application into the store. Involves the uploading and certification of an app's packages and listing data.
The beta release of the Windows 8 operating system.
A picture-based sign-in method that authenticates a user by checking gestures made on a picture of the user's own choosing.
To move an object, such as a window or an app, into a locked position on the screen.
The feature to help monitor and save on battery usage.
An album that contains a continuous roll of live viewfinder and captured photos and videos that have not been archived or moved to other folders.

A downloadable app that helps users choose which edition of Windows 8 is right for them, determine if their hardware can support it, determine the compatibility of apps and devices and assist with any changes that are needed, and then purchase and install it from within the app.
An online community that helps you choose how to respond to potential malware threats, and that helps to stop the spread of new malware infections.
An error-handling function of NTFS that is targeted only to corrupted areas to avoid lengthy checkdisk operations.
A process that repairs any errors that the online scan detects.
The feature that allows users to arrange all of their open windows on their screen using the mouse, keyboard, or the Snap Assist feature.
A mobile broadband or other network for which the provider bills according to data used, such as megabytes downloaded, messages sent, or webpages viewed.
A root certification authority that appears in the Trusted Root Certification Authorities console of the Windows operating systems and is trusted by the operating system.
A root certification authority that appears in the Trusted Root Certification Authorities console of the Windows operating systems and is trusted by the operating system.

An antimalware driver that loads early in the boot process, to evaluate the safety of the other drivers being loaded. Based on a comparison against historical data for those drivers, the antimalware driver returns information to the kernel, which makes initialization decisions for each driver.

An antimalware driver that loads early in the boot process, to evaluate the safety of the other drivers being loaded. Based on a comparison against historical data for those drivers, the antimalware driver returns information to the kernel, which makes initialization decisions for each driver.

An antimalware driver that loads early in the boot process, to evaluate the safety of the other drivers being loaded. Based on a comparison against historical data for those drivers, the antimalware driver returns information to the kernel, which makes initialization decisions for each driver.
A set of services used by Windows and Windows apps to access the user's current location.
Before Windows loads.
To repost a tweet from another Twitter user, sharing the tweet with one's own followers.
The credentials (user name and password) that a person uses to gain access to a service, network server, etc.

A price that reflects a representative value in other currencies. The specific price of a price tier that is shown in one currency will be close to the corresponding price in another currency. Foreign exchange, differences in taxation policies, and other market factors influence the determination of a price tier’s price that is shown in another currency.
Of or related to social networking.
The category of products given special prominence in the Store via editorial programming.

A value that developers specify in the app manifest for their Windows Store apps. Windows Store apps use capabilities to declare that the app requires programmatic access to protected user resources, such as the Pictures library, or connected devices, such as a webcam.
The process in which Microsoft tests an app to make sure it meets app requirements.
The process in which a developer tests an app to make sure it meets app requirements.
A user interface element that provides access to sharing files and info with other apps.
A user interface element that provides access to search in apps or on the PC.
A user interface element that provides access to external devices like media players or printers.
A user interface element that provides access to PC and app settings.
The boundary of a physical or rendered object, such as a display screen or window.
To transfer data such as files to a device or an app.
Pertaining to the chrome-free UI presentation mode that fills all or a portion of the display.
The download package that includes People, Messaging, Mail, and Calendar.
A feature of Internet Explorer 10 that allows users to easily switch between websites and their corresponding apps.

A Windows feature that enables users to connect computers with a simple tap gesture or by browsing for computers within wireless range. If two computers come within 3-4 centimeters of each other, or are tapped together, the operating system of each computer becomes aware of the other computer. Also, a user can browse for computers within wireless range that are advertising for a peer connection. The user can then connect the two computers to share content such as photos or links, or create a multi-player experience. If the connection is made using a tap gesture, the user can also publish and subscribe to messages transmitted during the tap.
A feature of Windows where a user's credentials are securely stored.
To take action on a message by either replying to the sender, to the sender and all recipients, or by forwarding the message to someone else.
A feature of Windows that provide right-click access from taskbar program buttons to the documents, pictures, songs, or websites a user frequently accesses.
A feature of Windows that provide right-click access from taskbar program buttons to the documents, pictures, songs, or websites a user frequently accesses.
A nonfinal release of Internet Explorer 10.
A visual interface where users enter a passcode, use a certain button combination or perform a certain gesture in order to activate the full functionality of a device.
The web browser component of Windows that provides a traditional and familiar browsing experience.
The touch-optimized, immersive web browser for Windows.
A feature that validates, signs, and stores boot information in the Trusted Platform Module chip to verify the integrity of the PC.
A gesture that enables proximity-based authentication between two devices.
To go to the next page on a site quickly by swiping across the page or clicking the Forward button.
A feature in Internet Explorer that enables users to go to the next page on a site quickly by swiping across the page or clicking the Forward button.
A button that shuts down or restarts the PC.

The operating system designed for enthusiasts and business/technical pros that includes all of the features in Windows 8, plus features for encryption, virtualization, PC management, and domain connectivity.

The operating system for PCs and tablets powered by x86 (32-bit) and AMD (64-bit) processors that includes an updated Windows Explorer, Task Manager, better multi-monitor support, and fast language switching.

The operating system only available pre-installed on PCs and tablets powered by ARM processors that helps enable new thin and lightweight form factors with impressive battery life. Windows RT includes touch-optimized versions of Microsoft Word, Excel, PowerPoint, and OneNote.
A downloadable pack that adds features to Windows 8 or Windows 8 Single Language editions to move them to a Windows 8 Pro edition with Windows Media Center installed.
An edition of Windows 8 that is available only through volume licensing.
An edition of Windows 8 designed to make Windows affordable to mainstream consumers in emerging markets.
A media pack add-on to Windows 8 Pro that upgrades the edition to include Windows Media Center.
The button or slider on tablets and convertible tablets that rotates the display.
An edition of Windows 8 Pro that contains Windows Media Center.
The release candidate release of the Windows 8 operating system.

An automated proactive scan that triggers when NTFS detects a corruption. The scan is equivalent to the scan phase of chkdsk and finds and logs all corruptions to an internal file. This scan runs during maintenance hours, can be triggered from the Explorer, or manually run from a command line. When this scan is running in the background, some NTFS operations may be blocked.

A registry setting that allows the DHCP client to transmit more messages to the server to obtain an IP address when the PC is in connected standby mode. This setting can increase power consumption but can also help resolve IP address (IPv4 or IPv6) problems more quickly.

A service within Remote Desktop Services responsible for aggregating RemoteApp programs and desktops that are published to end users from across the entire deployment. It ensure only users with appropriate rights can access published resources. The resources are used to display error messages that, for example, might say that the publishing service is unavailable. This can help the admin debug their deployment.
The capability to sign in to a PC by using a four-digit code.
A software setting that disables display rotation.
The automatic display of photos in Windows Photos in a grid-like pattern based on metadata from the photos that are connected to the user's account.
A function relevant to an app in use that is displayed on the app bar.
The charm that takes users to the Start screen.
The functionality that allows users to switch back to recently used apps.
The state that enables a PC to turn on instantly and have tiles and other services update even when the screen is off.
A collection of Windows and device settings that users can change grouped into one location.
A tablet hardware button with the Windows logo on it that's similar to the Windows key on a keyboard. Pressing the Power and Windows buttons simultaneously is the equivalent of pressing Ctrl+Alt+Del.
A rating of how safe an app is determined to be by SmartScreen, according to age, presence of digital certificate, and other criteria.
A feature that provides a progressive disclosure method that remains active only as long as the user holds (presses down) their finger on the touch surface.
The charm that provides access to the devices commands.
A hardware button that increases and decreases the sound volume.
The UI label that indicates a screen or monitor that is attached to a PC and that content can be projected on to.
An application that comes with a product key and DVD that allows users them to purchase Windows and activate their current copy of Windows from the client.
A report generated by OEMs for each OA 3.0 manufactured computer which is then sent to Microsoft for processing. This report includes the hardware hash value and Product Key ID.
A report generated by OEMs for each OA 3.0 manufactured computer which is then sent to Microsoft for processing. This report includes the hardware hash value and Product Key ID.
An application that runs on mobile devices such as a smart phone.
The version of software that's distributed to manufacturers to build into hardware they will make available when the final software is made generally available.
The version of software that's distributed to manufacturers to build into hardware they will make available when the final software is made generally available.
To reset a system using a method that restores PC settings to defaults but retains a user's files and personalization touches.
To reset a system so that all user customizations are removed.
A control that slows down the speed of panning from a user interaction.
The button that allows customers to finalize their purchase on a website.
The out-of-the-box encryption capabilities that are automatically included on PCs running Windows RT.
The button on a checkout screen that, when clicked, commits the buyer to a purchase agreement with the seller, as specified by EU guideline 2011/83/EU and other local laws.

The feature of Bing that enables customers to block sites containing adult (sexually explicit) content. Customers can choose from three levels of filtering: strict (hides adult text and image results); moderate (hides adult images only); and off (doesn't hide any search results).

An app that's downloaded from the Microsoft Store and installed automatically to the PC when a user attaches a certified device to the PC, provided that the device manufacturer has submitted the app to the Microsoft Store.
The set of look-and-feel elements (type, color, icons, etc.) that create a sense of brand and a cohesive user experience with Microsoft products.
The category of products (apps or games) that are current getting the best average overall rating by customers.

The pre-loaded app that allows users to better monitor and manage their data usage on their phone or PC. It can notify users when they are close to their cellular data limit and delay some data-intensive tasks until the phone or PC is connected to Wi-Fi.
The app that provides easy access to Help and how-to content as well as helpful tips for users.
The category of items that have recently started to gain in popularity.

The interface that enables users to see what is consuming the storage space on their phone, displaying the space used by apps, games, media, settings, and more. It also allows moving content from phone to SD card.
The category of items that is personalized for the current user.
The feature that allows you to "tap" a PC or phone against another device (or put it close to another device), and share content between the two.
The category of the most popular apps or games that the customer can download and use at no cost.
The category of the most popular apps or games that the customer must pay to use.
To put your finger on a touchscreen and then swipe it quickly, lifting your finger off the screen, in the direction you want.
A key used only once in a cryptographic communication.
An app that reads what is displayed on a screen and converts the input for presentation by means of non-visual output devices.
Technology that provides enhancements to other technology so that people with disabilities can use it.

The distribution mechanism for all channels of the consumer e-commerce and retail experience, including clients in Windows and Xbox, the web store (Microsoft.com/store), and the brick-and-mortar locations.

The distribution mechanism for all channels of the consumer e-commerce and retail experience, including clients in Windows and Xbox, the web store (Microsoft.com/store), and the brick-and-mortar locations.
A computer that has properties both of a tablet and a laptop.
A preference set by users in web browsers to indicate to websites that they do not want to be tracked.
A Web page that a user of a public-access network has to view and interact with for authentication, accepting terms of use, or security updates.
The time for which the cell(s) in a rechargeable battery can produce an electric current before the battery needs to be recharged.
A measure of the relative frequency with which data is accessed.
An optional Microsoft account sign-in method with which users can only sign in by entering both a password and a security code sent to them by the Microsoft account team.
The app that enables users to scan photos or documents using a connected scanner and save the images to a folder.
The app that enables users to scan photos or documents using a connected scanner and save the images to a folder.
The app that enables users to create and edit short videos to highlight memorable moments.
Essential data that is carried within a packet or other transmission unit, excluding the data required to get the packet delivered.
A circular control with one or more sliders that a user moves to change values.
To slide two fingers on a touchpad or similar device at the same time and with a relatively short distance between each other.
A placeholder on the Start screen that represents an app not yet installed on the PC.
A placeholder on the Start screen that represents an app not yet installed on the PC.
A service designed for consumers that runs on Windows or in a web browser.
To tap with two fingers on a touchpad or similar device at the same time and with a relatively short distance between each other.
The search result that is most relevant to a user.
The process of viewing and interacting with an existing Remote Desktop Protocol session initiated by another user.
The process of viewing and interacting with an existing Remote Desktop Protocol session initiated by another user.
A series of pictures that are continuously stored in the Camera app so the user can go "back" or "forward" in time from the moment they actually pressed the button to capture a photo.
To load content in the background before a user sees it.
The Windows app where users can save links to content (such as articles or videos) and then quickly return to them later.
The Windows app where users can save links to content (such as articles or videos) and then quickly return to them later.
The app that enables users to quickly annotate images, create simple drawings, and share them.
An account optimized for children that parents can control and customize.
A layer of a storage space that writes data to storage media of a particular speed based on performance, availability and recovery requirements.
A device that shares its Internet connection with other Wi-Fi-enabled devices.
A feature that lets enterprises securely remove only enterprise data from personal devices, without affecting any personal data.
The set of features that let employees use personal devices to access corporate information and services and let IT admins manage such devices.
The set of features that let employees use personal devices to access corporate information and services and let IT admins manage such devices.
A feature that replaces malware-infected system files with uninfected files from the cloud.
Organizations that are qualified to sell Microsoft product licenses through the Open License, Select License, and Enterprise Agreement programs.
The time recorded for an interval or a segment of a race.
The process of exporting a virtual machine and its snapshots while the virtual machine is running.
A method to render images to a display with a dedicated memory buffer inside video hardware.
Storage that supports multiple storage tiers within a pool and ways to maintain data in each storage tier.
A display that is connected through wireless communication.
A physical or electronic card storing currency that customers can use to buy apps and similar items.
likely to produce a situation in which one of several threads is waiting for the other thread(s) to do something
An administrative user who has been granted the permissions to add, remove, and modify administrative users and their administrative assignments.
A process that verifies whether installed software is genuine.
The collection of networking and system components that lets devices turn on instantly, keep apps and data up to date even when devices are sleeping, and use batteries more efficiently.
A touchpad that provides a consistent, accurate, and responsive experience for users.
A software package that includes all features and does not require a previous version of the relevant software to be installed on the user's computer.
The free web-based email service from Microsoft.
A service that tracks regions of storage and may move data between them based on an input/output policy or other administrator-specified rules.
A service that tracks regions of storage and may move data between them based on an input/output policy or other administrator-specified rules.
A single-threaded apartment the thread of which is the core UI thread for an application window.
A single-threaded apartment the thread of which is the core UI thread for an application window.
To redistribute data or resources more evenly in order to change the processing capacity.
A process of importing prepared data using a software procedure rather than the end user entering the information.
An identifier used by app developers and advertising networks to provide more relevant advertising to users by understanding which apps they use and how they use them.
A name of a person as it is shown in a user interface.
The category of items that have recently become available.
The app that allows users to connect remotely to a computer and access programs, files, and network resources as though they were sitting at the computer.
The app that allows users to connect remotely to a computer and access programs, files, and network resources as though they were sitting at the computer.
An arrow associated with a drop-down combo or list box or some toolbar buttons, indicating a list the user can view by clicking the arrow.
The official currency of South Korea.
A moveable strip in the user interface that divides the screen between two apps.
A file that is only available when a device is connected to the Internet so that the file’s data uses little space in the device’s storage.
A piece of equipment that is running an operating system.
The enterprise-oriented feature which enables organizations to provide their users with access to data and documents stored on their corporate computers from anywhere.
To show or share screen content in a display other than the primary display.
The website hosted by Microsoft where users can browse community-approved wiki articles, post questions and answers or start a discussion on technology-related topics.
An app that is included in the product when a user first starts using it.
A physical Microsoft Store location.

A process that allows for the release of contents–for example emails and their attachments, address books, and contact lists–to the next of kin of a deceased or incapacitated email account holder and/or for the closure of an email account.
A UI element that users can click to display information about a selected object.
To create an index.
To locate data based on an index.
The feature that allows the replacement of the Windows shell (explorer.exe) with a custom shell for specialized device scenarios.
The edition of Windows 8.1 that has the search engine in Internet Explorer defaulted to Bing.
The software update to Windows 8.1 that gives users a more familiar and convenient experience across touch, keyboard and mouse inputs and enables more affordable Windows device choices.
The software update to Windows RT 8.1 that gives users a more familiar and convenient experience across touch, keyboard and mouse inputs and enables more affordable Windows device choices.
The software update to Windows 8.1 Pro that gives users a more familiar and convenient experience across touch, keyboard and mouse inputs and enables more affordable Windows device choices.
